HEADLINE: South Korea Dissolves Ties That Once Bound the Press to the Powerful

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
As a vigorous, debate-filled democracy becomes entrenched here, South Korea is rapidly dismantling the press club system, an enduring symbol of the collusive relationship between the government and the news media.
 Starting a year ago at the presidential offices, known as the Blue House, press clubs -- in which reporters from major media outlets excluded other journalists and decided what to report, sometimes in conjunction with government officials -- have been eliminated in one government office after another. Where they survive, as in Seoul's Police Department, they are expected to go soon.
 Instead, shiny new briefing rooms have been built, their doors flung open to all. Although journalists and government officials are still groping for a new balance in their relationship, most believe that the changes will lead to the emergence of something rare in East Asia: a fiercely independent press. 
 The dismantling of the deep-rooted press club system, a vestige of the Japanese colonial rule that ended in 1945, resulted from the confluence of several events. In 2002, President Roh Moo Hyun was elected despite the fierce opposition of traditional outlets, especially conservative newspapers and television networks. At the same time, Internet-based alternative sources of information, popular among the young and generally supportive of Mr. Roh, have emerged as rivals to the traditional media here in the world's most wired nation.
 The speed of the change is particularly stunning because, in Japan, the press club system survives intact. Hyun Seung Yoon, 39, a reporter for The Korea Economic Daily and the former vice president of the Finance Ministry's press club, which was abolished on Dec. 29, said that in the past the government and the media were united.
 ''Fundamentally, it's better now,'' Mr. Hyun said. ''It's healthier now. The relationship that existed before was a collusive one.''
 When Mr. Roh came to power a year and a half ago, a priority was to make the government's relationship with the media more open, and to give ''equal opportunity to all media,'' said Jung Soon Kyun, the minister of the government information agency, who traveled to the United States, Japan, Germany and Britain to study how each government dealt with the media. The press club system had allowed the big media outlets to ''monopolize information'' and sometimes ''offer and receive personal favors,'' said the minister, a former reporter.
 For Mr. Roh, a political outsider who had not won the backing of the mainstream media during his election campaign, the abolition of the press club system also worked to his political advantage.
 Under the old system, members of the major news outlets controlled membership and expelled organizations that failed to abide by club rules. The club decided, sometimes through a senior member acting as a liaison with the government, what news to focus on, what to play down or, in some cases, what to suppress.
 The government paid for all the expenses the press club incurred, including phone bills, and even provided a secretary for the members. Until a few years ago, the government also paid for the reporters' air fare, hotel bills and other expenses whenever the president traveled.
 Under the new system, the government charges each reporter assigned to the Blue House about $50 a month to cover various fees. With reporters for any news organization, big or small, free to register, the number of Blue House reporters has increased to more than 300 from 90. 
 Press clubs exist all over the country, from the Blue House to the ministries to police precincts, said Lee Jae Kyoung, a journalism professor at Ewha Womans University and a former television reporter.
 ''The loser was always going to be the reader, the people's right to know,'' Mr. Lee said.
 Years ago, when Mr. Lee was a cub reporter covering a police precinct, the press club discovered some bad news involving a local tea manufacturer, he said. Instead of reporting the news, the club's senior members met with company officials, pocketed some cash and then treated the club members to a lavish dinner and drinks, he said.
 South Korea's press club system, like its bureaucracy and legal systems, was a holdover from Japanese colonialism, said Youn Jung Suk, a professor at the Sejong Institute specializing in Japan-Korea relations. After the end of World War II and the end of Japanese colonialism, South Korea's American occupiers decided to retain the press club system.
 ''It was easy to control Korea through this system,'' Mr. Youn said.
 South Korea's military leaders and a largely compliant press also shared the same belief, experts say, and so the movement to reform the press club system started only after South Korea began democratizing in the late 1980's.
 In Japan, a de facto one-party state for the last half century, only maverick politicians in a few places, like Kamakura and Nagano, have abolished the press clubs, saying they are not appropriate in a democracy. Press clubs still exist in government agencies, companies and institutions all over the country, curtailing the nature and level of information available to the public.
 The media revolution in South Korea has been almost completely ignored by Japan's own media, even though almost all have bureaus in Seoul. Japan's Newspaper Publishers and Editors Association argues that press clubs have officially been opened to non-members since 2002, though most Japanese journalists will acknowledge that, in practice, little has changed.
 Hiroshi Wada, an official at Japan's newspaper association, went so far as to deny the changes occurring here.
 ''We checked the Korean situation and we do not think press clubs in South Korea have been abolished,'' Mr. Wada said. ''It is that they allow everyone's participation freely, but press clubs still exist.''
 He added: ''So it is not that Japan is more conservative with regards to press clubs. We understand that South Korea has caught up with us.''
 Here in South Korea, there had been previous attempts to abolish the press club system, notably under former President Kim Dae Jung's administration. But the resistance from the established media was too strong.
 But in recent years, Internet-based news services, like OhmyNews.com, rose to challenge the big media outlets, and their influence has grown, particularly with the young.
 In 2001, one of OhmyNews's reporters was barred from attending a news conference at Inchon Airport because he did not belong to its press club. Oh Yeon Ho, the news service's chief executive, sued and won.
 ''Only a few years earlier, people's acceptance of privileged media had been embedded in our culture,'' Mr. Oh said. ''Now the idea of abolishing the press club has become mainstream.''
 In fact, Mr. Roh granted his first domestic interview as president to OhmyNews, signaling the beginning of a new era. The changes have been hard to swallow for the mainstream media, but most acknowledge that they have been positive.
 ''Without the press club system, we can no longer maintain embargoes or -- it's an extreme example -- even abolish news items,'' said Shin Kyoung Min, deputy managing director for MBC, a major television network. ''Inside the press clubs, we did sometimes do that, though not often. The fact that everything is now open to all the media, that's a good change for everybody.''

HEADLINE: Building the Bones of a Downtown Nassau

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
ON Long Island, which has myriad suburban communities but no downtown, and where cars are seen as extensions of their owners' personalities, talk of expanding mass transit has never been warmly received or deemed necessary.
 Now Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, has presented an ambitious plan to create a downtown in central Nassau that will include a major public transit system that connects this ''hub'' to the rest of the county at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars. Many call him visionary, but others see his efforts as completely impractical.
 ''This is one of the most ambitious projects in the country around the idea of smart growth,'' said Jon Orcutt, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a transit advocacy group. ''It's just revolutionary in the way it looks at a suburban county in terms of creating a whole new dense center with mass transit.'' 
 But even fans of the plan wonder if it will ever become reality.
 ''I think it's great,'' said Viki De Jong, chairwoman of the Citizens Committee for Civic Action, a group in central Nassau. ''And this is not an attack on their commitment or ability, but I just don't know if it's possible to pull it off.''
 Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, said linking the hub to other parts of the county by rail would make sense. But in 1998 he helped oversee a hub study for Mr. Suozzi's predecessor, Thomas S. Gulotta, that met with considerable local opposition. ''I suspect Mr. Suozzi will run into the same conflict,'' Dr. Koppelman said. ''It's relatively easy to put these concepts down on paper. The difficulty is in getting them accepted.''
 Mr. Gulotta's hub proposal essentially went nowhere. Mr. Suozzi revived discussions about the Nassau hub about a year ago and will spend about $1 million, mostly in federal grants, to study how best to move people into and out of the area without increasing congestion on the county's clogged roads.
 The goal, Mr. Suozzi said, is to encourage transit-oriented development in the center of the county, which, he added, is fundamental to the ''new suburbia'' he envisions. Mass transit will make property around the hub more valuable and more attractive for development, he reasoned.
 The hub area includes the 70-acre Nassau Coliseum property, which is owned by the county. Mr. Suozzi and the owner of the New York Islanders hockey team, Charles B. Wang, have been negotiating for months over the building of a new arena and possible additional redevelopment of the property.
 ''We have to figure out a way to continue to grow while still preserving the quality of life that allows us to keep our neighborhoods with single-family homes and beautiful front lawns,'' Mr. Suozzi said. ''We have to do something dramatic, because if we don't change the way we look at things, property taxes will continue to go up, services will go down and traffic will get worse.''
 The hub proposal is still preliminary. Patricia Bourne, the county planning director, and Robert M. Brickman, the manager for the hub study, said they hoped to narrow the alternatives for more detailed study sometime in September.
 The plan now includes a mass transit loop around the hub with lines connecting the hub south to Freeport along the Meadowbrook Parkway, north to Oyster Bay and Glen Cove and southwest to Valley Stream along existing Long Island Rail Road lines, and east to Hicksville on an old railroad right-of-way. County officials have not determined what mode of transportation would be used but are considering light rail trains, automated guideway trains that run without drivers or rapid transit vehicles, which are buses designed to look like trains and run in special lanes to bypass traffic.
 Many questions remain. These include where the money to build the system and operate it would come from; who would operate and maintain it; whether communities along the routes would allow a new transit system to run through their neighborhoods; and whether Long Islanders would even be willing to get out of their cars to ride such a system.
 ''People say this is crazy and that suburbia and cars are one and the same,'' Mr. Suozzi said. ''But 20 years ago, people would have said that being required to wear a seatbelt was crazy, and 10 years ago, people would have said that a smoking ban in restaurants was crazy.''
 He is convinced, he said, that if given a transit system that can get them to the Nassau Coliseum or to work in the hub in less time than it takes now to drive on the county's congested roads, people will opt for a transit pass. ''There's enough frustration with traffic,'' he said. ''And especially with gas prices where they are now, people are beginning to realize that this is something we have to do.'' 
 The notional hub runs east to Eisenhower Park, south to Hempstead Turnpike, west to Garden City's Franklin Avenue and north to the L.I.R.R. Main Line. It includes parts of Mineola, Carle Place, Westbury, Garden City and Hempstead. Major institutions and locations include the Nassau Coliseum, the Mitchel Field athletic complex, Hofstra University, Nassau Community College, the Cradle of Aviation Museum, several major office complexes and the Roosevelt Field mall and other large shopping areas along Old Country Road.
 The transit loop that Mr. Suozzi envisions is similar to the one proposed by Mr. Gulotta, but he has greatly expanded the system by proposing connections to Oyster Bay, Freeport, Hicksville and Valley Stream, connecting to or annexing parts of the Long Island Rail Road. ''We wanted to make the hub the downtown of Long Island,'' he said. ''To do that, it has to have spokes connecting it to the North Shore, the South Shore, New York City to the west and Suffolk County to the east.''
 The 1998 study was financed largely by the Town of Hempstead and was done mainly by the Long Island Regional Planning Board. It proposed using either light rail trains, an elevated ''people mover'' or elevated trolleys in a loop around a hub that also connected to the Long Island Rail Road. The study foundered when civic groups harshly criticized plans to build a main station for the new line in Carle Place, but it nonetheless helped obtain much of the federal funding that Mr. Suozzi has been using for his planning effort.
 Many civic and business leaders who have participated in the county's exploratory meetings on the current proposal praise Mr. Suozzi's efforts as an improvement over the earlier study because the process has been more open to the public and has had a broader focus on the hub's impact on the rest of the county.
 ''The original study was too limited in scope to be of any value,'' said Neal Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, a civic group in Massapequa. He called the 1998 plan ''a glorified parking lot shuttle'' because it would have mainly appealed to people headed to the Coliseum who would avoid traffic at the Coliseum by parking farther away. By expanding the study to include connections to other parts of the county, Mr. Lewis said, the plan now also addresses the mass transit needs of thousands of Long Islanders with jobs in the office complexes in the hub.
 But since the study now takes in planning and development issues that affect the entire county, it has come under fire for being too simplistic and for not adequately considering the myriad concerns of villages and hamlets along the proposed routes.
 ''We would have anticipated an even broader range of people involved and more creativity on the land use side,'' said Eric Alexander, director of Vision Long Island, a nonprofit group that promotes ''smart growth'' initiatives. He said, for example, that proposed stops for the new system should be located where there might be land use changes that would be appropriate for transit, like new housing or office developments.
 ''The magic connection between land use and transportation is what we're looking for, along with some real civic input, and we haven't seen that yet,'' he said. ''I'd hate to see another 500 angry people at a hearing two years from now, because if you have one bad hearing on this, people will run for the hills. We lost five years after 1998, and we should be doing everything we can to make sure that doesn't happen again.''
 But Mr. Suozzi says that combining transportation and land use needs are a priority for his staff and the consultant hired to complete the study, STV Inc. -- an engineering and architectural firm that has also worked on the AirTrain at Kennedy Airport and the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line in New Jersey. ''We know that the only way for the county to have some targeted development and to fix the traffic is to marry the two concepts,'' Mr. Suozzi said.
 Bertram Donley, a former president of the Garden City Chamber of Commerce, said that he feared that although county officials had made a point of inviting representatives from different municipalities and interest groups, they had not worked hard enough to completely win them over. ''They need to do more to reach out to the zoning authorities, the towns and villages, and the landowners that would be affected by this system,'' he said.
 Officials of Garden City, for example, have already expressed concern about the plan because it would involve converting a freight rail line that runs through the village and is now used only once a year by Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to transport circus animals and equipment to the Coliseum.
 ''It would be easier to tell the civic groups in Garden City that we're trying space travel for the whole village to Mars,'' Mr. Donley said, ''and it would probably be more accepted.'' 
 Mr. Suozzi said he knew village opposition would be a big hurdle to overcome, but he said he hoped to find the funds to place the new rail or bus line essentially below grade, so that local residents would neither hear nor see it.
 Mineola officials also have concerns about the county's plan because it would use the Mineola train station as the main connection from the Long Island Rail Road to the hub loop. ''I think it's unfortunate that the county has not yet looked at our downtown area to see if we could absorb the additional cars and traffic that kind of connection would bring to Mineola,'' said Mayor Jack Martins. ''The county has an obligation to make sure it doesn't negatively impact on our residents.''
 County officials said such concerns would be addressed as the study continues and the plan becomes more specific and detailed. 
 County officials face many considerations like those of Garden City and Mineola. But while balancing the concerns of the county and the more narrow interests of villages and homeowners, the county also must referee the contest between what is achievable and what potential riders might want.
 Just choosing the mode of transportation is fraught with potential for disagreement. Some residents have pushed for a trolley system, which would be more picturesque and therefore more palatable. But county officials have ruled trolleys out because of low passenger capacity and because they would still have to steer through congestion. A light rail system could keep costs down but would be much more expensive than a rapid transit bus system, which is unlikely to appeal to suburban travelers but is the most likely given current federal financing possibilities.
 Many of the major players in the future of the system remain guarded in their assessment of Mr. Suozzi's plan. Mike Deery, a spokesman for the Town of Hempstead, which controls zoning for much of the area included in the proposed system, said: ''While the town supports the concept in general, there's still very little detail available because the study is so preliminary and we would have to assess how the details will impact on neighborhoods and business districts before we made any decisions.''
 Under the proposal, the Long Island Rail Road would have to cede its Oyster Bay and West Hempstead lines to the new system, and L.I.R.R. officials also remain circumspect. The railroad ''is supportive of the study's objectives to improve mobility and economic vitality in our service area in the Nassau Hub,'' it said in a statement, but it added that the study was still in a ''very early conceptual stage and would require additional study.''
 Mr. Orcutt, of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, said, ''There will be many nimby fights to fight and territorial battles to wage before anything gets done, but that would be true anywhere.''
 The competition for federal dollars is also a concern, but Mr. Orcutt noted that funds had already been secured for major transportation projects for Long Island like the plan to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal and for a third track on the railroad's Main Line. ''The important thing is to get the first round of capital projects for the hub identified and when the time comes, to get the towns and villages to deal with the zoning issues,'' he said. ''It's all very complex and will require a lot of consensus, but this could be the next big thing for Long Island.''
 To continue the study process, Representative Carolyn McCarthy, whose district includes much of the hub area, has included $7 million for a comprehensive environmental impact study of the proposed system in the proposed federal highway and transit bill. She said she was a strong supporter of the project because ''the only way we can continue to bring industry into the county is to lay out lines for transportation.'' She has taken the lead on securing federal funds for the project, but she said she felt she had the support of her colleagues in the Island's Congressional delegation.
 For her part, Ms. McCarthy does not think that the hub proposal is too ambitious. ''They made fun of the Big Dig in Boston too, but it's making a big difference now,'' she said, referring to a huge highway project in downtown Boston. ''Sometimes it takes being a little visionary to see something gets done.''
 Mitchell H. Pally, the vice president for government affairs at the Long Island Association, said business leaders were behind the hub project because ''that's the center of the Nassau County economy and one of the major centers of Long Island's economy and you can't sit around and say we're not going to try to do something ambitious just because we might not get the funding for it.''
 He pointed to plans for new subway and rail lines in New York City and said, ''We should do no less on Long Island.''

HEADLINE: Mad Words Ping-Pong Across the Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
IN an association that predates the Revolutionary War by more than 100 years, Long Island and Connecticut have had some scrapes but have generally coexisted peacefully on opposite sides of Long Island Sound.
 No more. Not just one but three intertwining disputes, all involving the Sound, have caused a rupture like none before. ''I don't know of any other era in which relations were worse,'' said Christopher Collier, the Connecticut state historian. 
 In a sign of how deep the enmity runs, Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, is accusing Connecticut of conduct unbecoming a neighbor. ''We always expected it would be OPEC that would cut our power supply, not our own neighbors in Connecticut,'' Mr. Levy said last week. 
 It may take a scorecard to track the three disputes. In brief, they involve the cross-Sound electric cable, a rapidly escalating battle over a plan to dump mountains of dredged spoils from Connecticut into the Sound and a proposed natural gas pipeline. 
 There was a furious dispute over the Cross Sound Cable, which was shut down by Spencer Abraham, the federal energy secretary, on May 7, just as the weather was warming and Long Island was entering a period of high demand for electricity. The 330-megawatt line carries power in both directions, but during summer's heat, the flow is overwhelmingly to Long Island.
 Mr. Abraham, ruling that the energy emergency that began with the blackout last August had passed, rescinded an order that had allowed the cable to operate since then. Connecticut officials say the 24-mile cable, which runs from New Haven to Shoreham, has not been buried deep enough and violates state environmental laws.
 Although the energy secretary's action clearly delighted Connecticut officials, there was anger across the water. The Long Island Power Authority and Nassau and Suffolk Counties said that they would cooperate in trying to reverse Mr. Abraham's decision. Richard M. Kessel, the chairman of the authority, warned that without the cable, Long Island faced electric shortages and up to $18 million in extra costs to pay for more expensive replacement power.
 Bad feelings about Connecticut ran rampant. In Washington, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, proposed a bill that would put the cable back in operation, and the Long Island delegation in the House joined in seeking a reversal of Mr. Abraham's ruling. 
 Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general, lambasted Suffolk for going into federal court last month to try to have the line reopened. He said Connecticut would fight to keep it turned off. ''The cable isn't buried at the right depth, and therefore it is illegal,'' he said. ''Blasting to put it at the right depth threatens the Sound.''
 Mr. Levy said that Connecticut was being a stickler about the cable's compliance with its environmental laws but was willing enough to countenance a far greater environmental insult: a proposal to dump 20 million cubic yards of contaminated spoils, mostly dredged from Connecticut harbors and marinas, into the Sound.
 ''This is the ultimate hypocrisy for Connecticut to complain about a cable with no evidence of any environmental problems while looking the other way as millions of cubic yards of heavy metals and fill are dumped in our Long Island Sound,'' Mr. Levy said.
 The proposal, which is awaiting further action by the Environmental Protection Agency, is to dump dredged spoils at two underwater sites over a 20-year period. One site is two miles north of Lloyd Point in the Village of Lloyd Harbor and 2.5 miles south of Long Neck Point near Stamford, Conn. The other site is 10 miles north of Shoreham and 5.6 miles south of South End Point near East Haven, Conn. Both are in Connecticut waters and have been used before for dumping dredged spoils but never in such quantities.
 The E.P.A. says the spoils will be tested before dumping to screen out the worst contamination. An environmental study has said that no lasting damage would result, but New York officials, groups and residents opposed to the dumping have called the study flawed. 
 In Washington, sometime allies were at odds over the matter. Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman and the Congressional delegation from Connecticut vigorously support the dumping plan. The dredging of Connecticut harbors, Mr. Lieberman said, is ''critical to Connecticut's maritime industry and the state's ability to ensure the safe navigation of the Sound.''
 But New York's senators, Mrs. Clinton and Charles E. Schumer -- Democrats, like Senators Dodd and Lieberman -- strongly oppose the plan. ''We cannot let short-term economics overtake long-term environmental concerns,'' Senator Clinton said in a statement announcing the bill to prevent dumping of contaminants in the Sound. 
 The bill would require that New York sign off on any dumping plan even when the dump site is in Connecticut waters. Representative Timothy Bishop, Democrat of Southampton, filed a companion bill in the House, and other House members from Long Island lined up to oppose the dumping plan. 
 On the matter of the natural gas pipeline, roles have reversed. The Connecticut Congressional delegation and state officials are up in arms about a May 6 decision by Commerce Secretary Donald Evans overruling Connecticut's environmental objections. 
 The Islander East pipeline, a project of KeySpan and Duke Energy, would bring natural gas from Canada to Suffolk County by way of Connecticut. Senator Lieberman expressed outrage over Mr. Evans's decision, saying that it usurped state powers. ''Through this decision, the Department of Commerce has signed off on the creation of a 23-mile scar across the heart of the Sound,'' he said in a statement.
 The underwater section of the pipeline would extend from Branford, Conn., to Shoreham. The project has been approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, but it will require a permit from the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection before the Army Corps of Engineers grants permission for construction to begin.
 As the intra-agency jousting continued, matters turned rather personal for two members of Congress. Representative Steve Israel, the Democrat who is chairman of the Long Island Sound Congressional Caucus, said a Connecticut colleague in the House -- he would not identify him -- gave him a private talking-to recently:
 ''He became rather irate, and said to me, 'Listen, you Long Islanders made the decision to shut down Shoreham, and now you want Connecticut to bail you out.'
 ''I said to him, 'You Connecticutters made the decision to dump dredged spoils in Long Island Sound, and now you want Long Island to bail you out.' And the conversation ended there.''

HEADLINE: Another Step For New Haven

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
HARD up for a place to open a regional theater 39 years ago, two Yale graduates were pleased to find an empty warehouse among the slabs of ribs and sausage in a food terminal directly off Interstate 95, on the Long Wharf in New Haven. Theatergoers, particularly suburbanites scared by tales of high crime in New Haven, pulled off the highway into the Long Wharf Theater's parking lot, watched the show, got back into their cars and headed home. They could hardly say they had visited New Haven. But back then, not being downtown was better for the theater's business. 
 New Haven's reputation has changed in the past few years. The city's nightlife has a brighter cast, and people walk the streets after dark in many neighborhoods. An arts district stretches from Yale University down into the Ninth District neighborhood that borders the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum. Restaurants are flourishing. 
 So on June 3, when the Long Wharf Theater announced that it planned to leave its longtime home for the inner city, it reflected another step in the city's cultural shift. It also helped that the state promised the theater a $30 million grant as part of a larger project that some say confirms New Haven's status as a vibrant work in progress, but that others say will be a capstone of its revitalization. 
 Gov. John G. Rowland was battling in court last week to avoid the spotlight at House impeachment hearings, but he stepped readily onto the stage at the Long Wharf Theater June 3 to announce the state's commitment to a $230 million development project in downtown New Haven. 
 Along with the $30 million grant to Long Wharf, Mr. Rowland pledged another $150 million to move Gateway Community College downtown and create parking for both sites. The plan also includes a 300-room hotel and conference center, retail shops and 280 residential units. A crucial part of the deal was the city's promise to level the Coliseum, a Modernist landmark that many in New Haven, including its mayor, believe to be little more than a Great Wall that blocks the view into their city.
 Some in New Haven see the project as a small piece of the puzzle that is New Haven -- a city of about 125,000 people -- and that includes Mayor John DeStefano Jr. ''What strikes people is that this is four blocks of city land -- big in size, in scale -- but does it change New Haven? No,'' Mr. DeStefano said in a telephone interview. ''What drives me nuts is that people think that one or two projects will change the city. I'm excited about it, but let's keep it in perspective.'' 
 Mr. DeStefano, who on June 3 praised Mr. Rowland for supporting his city, in January had called for his resignation. 
 But others see the project as the final piece in New Haven's revitalization. And that includes Marc S. Ryan, the state's budget director. ''If you look at New Haven, there's one remaining redevelopment area that hasn't really been touched,'' Mr. Ryan said in a telephone interview, ''the Coliseum and the Ninth Square area. And that's why this was extremely important to New Haven. It's not the end, but my point is that this is one of the last remaining areas of downtown that needs to be developed in a major way.''
 A new Long Wharf Theater will, optimistically, take its place downtown for the 2009-2010 theater season, after it completes its own drive to raise another $30 million. It will include a 500-seat theater featuring classic plays and contemporary works with wide appeal, and a 300-seat theater staging ''more adventurous work,'' said Michael Stotts, Long Wharf's managing director.
 ''What's attractive is the long-term opportunities, being close to other cultural amenities, to restaurants, to retail,'' Mr. Stotts said. ''There's an energy in New Haven that frankly didn't exist 5 to 10 years ago, and it's exciting.''
 The project is also the last in the state's refurbishing of its college campuses. The state has committed $3.8 billion over 15 years to the renovation of public colleges, which include the University of Connecticut, the Connecticut State University system and the community college system, Mr. Ryan said, including the Gateway-Long Wharf project. ''It was a hefty price tag,'' he said, ''and the final anchor.'' 
 The new project is also the final one in a number of large downtown revitalization efforts backed by Mr. Rowland that mix education and the arts. Adriaen's Landing, a large mixed-use development being built in downtown Hartford, will include a science center. A few blocks away, a recently relocated Capitol Community College draws thousands of students into the city daily. In downtown Waterbury, the University of Connecticut opened a satellite campus, a magnet school for the arts will be open this year nearby and the 2,700-seat Palace Theater is being renovated. Bridgeport, New London, Torrington and Stamford have all had a significant numbers of state dollars marked for arts and education initiatives. 
 The New Haven project had been in the thinking stages, then the talking stages, among state and local leaders for at least four years, Mr. Ryan said. As other cities had drawn community colleges to their downtowns and received large infusions of state money for arts institutions, the Ninth District plan in New Haven had been stuck on a couple fronts. 
 First, New Haven didn't want to pay millions of dollars to raze the Coliseum. Neither did the state. The potential demolition of the Coliseum, which has been closed for business since 2002, had also attracted vocal opponents. The controversy created a stalemate. The Coliseum sat, unused, a deteriorating 20th-century architectural landmark that New Haven's economic development administrator, Henry Fernandez, characterized in a New Haven Advocate interview as ''a landmark to architectural failure.''
 The city gave in first. ''It was a case of investing $6 million to get $180 million,'' Mr. DeStefano said, referring to the cost of demolishing the Coliseum. ''A community college, a great theater, parking, a hotel, housing, hundreds of jobs and increased tax revenues, for 6 million bucks. A pretty good leverage of resources, I'd say.''
 At least one New Haven preservationist is staying levelheaded about the Coliseum's demise. ''There may be people who value the Coliseum, and I may even be one of them, but their population in New Haven is very small,'' said Robert Grzywacz, an architect, a member of the New Haven Preservation Trust and a former volunteer at the Long Wharf Theater. ''The mayor hears from people outside the city that the Coliseum is a wonderful building, but not from people inside the city. Bringing more arts to downtown is obviously what downtown needs. Even though the Coliseum was conceived as a gateway to downtown, it also creates a sort of no-man's land.''
 The state avoided the dispute. ''In one sense, I don't believe the Coliseum is viable for refurbishment,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''But clearly the controversy had something to do with the state's decision on the issue. With the exception of very few instances, we don't put our money into something like that.''
 State officials also had not been not sure whether the Long Wharf Theater would be able to raise a matching $30 million to put up a new building on the Coliseum site. The theater's attendance was 100,000 this year, counting 9,000 subscribers. The past season was a difficult one for single-ticket sales, Mr. Stotts said, who faulted the war in Iraq and the overall economy. To compensate, the theater will open its next season with a musical that has broad appeal, ''Guys and Dolls.'' Theater officials said they hoped that works by playwrights with greater name recognition, like Eugene O'Neill and Tom Stoppard, would also help ticket sales. The theater, which has sent 16 plays to Broadway and produced three Pulitzer-Prize-winning world premieres, announced recently that it will have balanced its budget and eliminated a deficit by the end of this month. A study done by an independent consultant, Catherine Creager, in 1998, determined that a move downtown would increase the theater's annual attendance by about 20,000 people. 
 Still, Long Wharf officials were not sure that they wanted to leave the sides of beef to move to the Coliseum site. ''There was a little bit of back and forth with the Long Wharf,'' Mr. Ryan said. He said the state also did not know until a few months ago what bringing Gateway Community College downtown would cost; the school has 11,000 students between its Long Wharf and North Haven campuses. 
 The downtown location, at the edge of Ninth Square, provides a distinctly different feel from Long Wharf. In Ninth Square, brick and brownstone buildings in a hodgepodge of architectural styles -- from Queen Anne to Georgian Revival to Italianate -- form a contiguous facade that fronts the street. Starting at the southeast edge of the New Haven Green, the neighborhood is on the National Register of Historic Places and is part of the oldest section of New Haven. Although redevelopment efforts have focused on Ninth Square at least since 1994 and restaurants and galleries have opened, the neighborhood has still struggled. 
 Despite the omnipresence of Yale and the geographic solidity of the city's original plan, which divvied up New Haven into a grid of nine squares with the New Haven Green at its center, many New Haven neighborhoods have suffered since the end of World War II. Thousands of residents moved to the suburbs, and highways chopped the city into pieces, shredding the original grid. 
 With state and New Haven money, those pieces are being reunited, if sometimes only metaphorically, Mr. DeStefano said. ''This project is a piece of the puzzle,'' he said. ''The Long Wharf Theater in the downtown core will add value where it never did out in Long Wharf, and so it's a piece. Just like all the apartments we're building downtown, all the restaurants, the Pfizer building, the retail. All the pieces that make a whole.''
 Mr. Grzywacz, the architect, likened the project to the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, a $125 million three-theater project being built in an old railroad yard on the banks of the Mississippi River. The State of Minnesota gave the theater a grant of $25 million, about 20 percent of the total cost. ''We're a large regional theater, and Long Wharf is also,'' said Tom Proehl, the Guthrie's managing director. ''But they're getting 50 percent funded, which is amazing.''
 Mr. Rowland has been generous, Long Wharf officials said. Mr. Stotts said he had not seen that level of financial commitment to the arts in other places. 
 ''These expenditures are unprecedented in 15 years,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''We didn't put more than tens of millions into these systems before he came into office. This is part of the legacy of the governor.'' 
 That, and the threat of impeachment. With Mr. Rowland accused of ethics violations, a federal investigation and an impeachment inquiry dogging his administration and 23 percent of the state's residents saying in a recent University of Connecticut poll that the most important issue facing state government right now is ethics and corruption (just 20 percent said the budget situation was the foremost issue), arts and education may be the legacy that Mr. Rowland prefers.

ORGANIZATION: YALE UNIVERSITY (93%) Long Wharf Theater (New Haven); Gateway Community College (New Haven, Conn); Veterans Memorial Coliseum (New Haven, Conn)

HEADLINE: Sarah Margon, Samuel Chaltain

 BODY:
Sarah Michelle Margon and Samuel Spelman Chaltain were married last evening at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass. Charles C. Haynes, a friend of the couple, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the ceremony. 
 Ms. Margon, 27, is keeping her name. She graduated from Wesleyan University and is a candidate for a master's degree in foreign service at Georgetown University. From 2001 to 2003 she was policy analyst at the Center for National Security Studies, a civil liberties organization in Washington, where she specialized in counterterrorism legislation. She is the daughter of Marilyn and Arthur Margon, of Brooklyn. Her father is the principal in charge of the Manhattan office of RCG, a company based in Berkeley, Calif., that does real-estate economic forecasting. Her mother is a health-care consultant in Brooklyn. 
 Mr. Chaltain, 33, works for the First Amendment Center, a program in Arlington, Va., of the Freedom Forum; he is a director of the First Amendment Schools Project, a national school-reform initiative. He graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received a master's degree in American studies from William and Mary. 
 His mother, Cornelia Maude Spelman of Evanston, Ill., is a former clinical social worker and the author of ''The Way I Feel,'' a series of children's books about grief, jealousy and other topics published by Albert Whitman & Company. His father, Victor H. Chaltain Jr. of Hanover, N.H., is a building contractor.
 Ms. Margon first heard about her future husband in the fall of 1997, when he was a soccer coach at the school her brother, Andrew, attended in Brooklyn. 
 ''My mother kept telling me I needed to come home and meet my brother's cute new soccer coach,'' recalled Ms. Margon, who was at college when the suggestion was put forth.
 Picturing some sort of nerd, she did not race home. In the meantime, Mr. Chaltain got to know the other members of Ms. Margon's family. He saw them at school events, strolled the sidelines with her father before soccer games, and even came to their house for an end-of-year team party. 
 In June 1998, Ms. Margon chaperoned her brother's eighth-grade graduation dance. At the end of the dance some of the other chaperones invited Ms. Margon to attend a party Mr. Chaltain was giving in his apartment.
 She went. ''I thought, 'I might as well at least see what he looks like,' '' she said.

HEADLINE: Flying Is No Fun, but It May Get Better

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
ON June 1, the day after Memorial Day and the traditional start of the summer travel season, the scene at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport, the nation's busiest, captured the state of the American flying experience in a nutshell. 
 Holiday traffic overwhelmed security guards, and thousands of passengers waited two hours or more to be screened. Lines of travelers wound past the ticket counters and through baggage claim areas.
 One thing to note: The counters at Delta were packed, but so were those of its low-fare challenger, AirTran. The difference was, the new guy is making money. Delta could soon go bankrupt. 
 The crowds seem to bear out forecasts of the busiest travel summer in four years, but even that may not save America's traditional airlines -- the companies that sold the country on air travel in the first place. 
 That may be bad news for the tens of thousands of employees of those companies, but consumers may be looking at a considerably brighter future -- one in which they will be offered more choices in how they fly, where they leave from and what they pay. 
 Almost all the major airlines have suffered deep losses since summer 2000 -- the so-called summer of hell when delays and congestion clogged the nation's airports, enraging passengers and causing concern among regulators that the air traffic system was becoming overburdened. And then came the plunge in air travel after 9/11. 
 Since then, the airlines have collectively laid off more than 100,000 employees, mothballing more than 1,200 aircraft and banishing free cocktails and food from their flights. They also got a $15 billion bailout from Congress after the attacks.
 This is the year the airlines hoped they would recover. Instead, they could lose $3 billion, and what's more, the business they're in seems to be changing right out from under them. 
 The changes, said Alfred E. Kahn, who oversaw airline deregulation in the late 1970's as the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, have combined ''to turn a relatively prosperous and pretty competitive industry into a basket case.'' 
 The major companies were booming as recently as the late 1990's. Since then, however, deregulation has, in effect, hollowed out the old industry and begun building a new one. 
 The primary problem, said Mr. Kahn, a professor in political economy at Cornell University, is that the major carriers have been unable to find a strategy for competing against low-fare airlines like Southwest, JetBlue and AirTran, which grow stronger each year.
 For example, last month Southwest began flying out of Philadelphia, long dominated by US Airways. US Airways charged as much as $1,400 for a last-minute round-trip flight to Las Vegas, but Southwest charges no more than $598, and often hundreds of dollars less for the same trip. Southwest, given its lower costs, can make money on those fares, while US. Airways cannot. With low-fare carriers handling 25 percent of the industry's business now -- compared with just 6 percent at the start of the 1990's -- some experts see that figure climbing to 40 percent by the end of this decade. 
 Thus far, the major airlines have fought back primarily by adding flights and slashing their fares, as they did to defeat People Express, the first of the no-frills carriers, over a decade ago. But they are bleeding red ink on each of those flights.
 Among the most troubled is United Airlines, which is in bankruptcy protection. US Airways, which technically defaulted on the loan package that helped it emerge from Chapter 11 protection last year, is warning it might go back into bankruptcy unless it gets union wage cuts. Delta Airlines says it, too, may seek bankruptcy protection. 
 The rise of the small airlines is sweet vindication for Donald Burr, the creator of People Express, which became an instant success in the 1980's with minimal service and cheap prices, only to vanish a decade later in the face of the major carriers' counterattack. 
 Mr. Burr says he believes that more change is coming. And he adds that it could be good for consumers. He foresees travelers finding alternatives to crowded terminals and jets backed up on runways, and has teamed with the former American Airlines chief executive Robert Crandall to form an air-taxi service that will serve underused small airports. 
 To Mr. Burr, the future lies in decentralization, with more small carriers serving different kinds of customers, at different levels of luxury and convenience. In other words, people may be able to shop for the kind of air service they want, just as they shop for, say, the kind of car they want.
 ''We had a era when everyone believed bigger was better,'' said Mr. Burr. ''That's not true anymore.''
 Professor Kahn, who cheerfully accepts the blame for breaking up the old aviation system, says that system ''had all kinds of advantages, but it was predicated on people being willing to sit still and accept prices that were outrageous.'' 
 Airports may be crowded, lines may be long, but the prices have put air travel in the reach of more and more people. ''That's why we deregulated,'' Mr. Kahn said.

HEADLINE: The Changing Face Of Society Hill

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
EVERY city has its neighborhoods that speak of comfort and affluence, of historic architecture and idiosyncratic businesses that create a distinct sense of place. In Philadelphia, the archetypal one may be Society Hill, which is famous for its cobblestone streets, its charming houses and, increasingly, its high real estate prices. 
 In part because of the demand for town houses there, a developer is now beginning to put up 35 new town houses with bay windows and mansard roofs that will be inspired by their historic counterparts but not exact duplicates. Although new town houses have been built here and there in Society Hill, this is the first such large development in decades. 
 This month, the roofless shells of six town houses will be leveled to make way for the new houses, which will also sit on land now occupied by a parking lot. 
 ''There is a trend back to city living, and I'm betting prices in Philadelphia will continue to escalate,'' said Arthur Fefferman, president of AFC Realty Capital of Manhattan, which is developing the homes with the Altman Group of Philadelphia. He said the site -- on Lombard Street close to where the Declaration of Independence was signed -- is among the last development parcels in Society Hill.
 The houses, with three and four bedrooms, are expected to sell for $900,000 to $1.4 million. That is in line with prices for similarly sized houses in that area, according to Mary Hall, a regional sales and marketing manager at Prudential Fox & Roach, which will be marketing them. She said that of the 92 houses that have sold so far this year, 26 were priced from $500,000 to around $1 million. 
 The housing development is part of a burst of new construction in a city that like so many others in the Northeast is trying to regenerate rundown neighborhoods. 
 Philadelphia has devised tax incentives to help stem the flow of people out of the city, which lost 4.3 percent of its population from 1990 to 2000. Starting in 1997, developers were offered 10-year tax abatements to convert commercial buildings downtown to rentals and condominiums, and now they are being offered similar incentives to build new housing. 
 For developers the abatements ''take some risk off the project and for buyers they mean a savings,'' said Joanne Davidow, a vice president at the local Prudential Fox & Roach Realtors. She said buyers of homes in the $1 million range, for instance, could save up to $100,000 in taxes over 10 years. 
 Initially, the wave of new and converted housing washed over established areas like Rittenhouse Square and Society Hill, but in recent years it has gained momentum and spread to neighboring downtown districts like Northern Liberties and Bella Vista.
 In Center City alone, 100 commercial buildings have been or will be converted to produce about 5,000 market-rate rental and condominium apartments. And some 849 one-family houses as well as rental and condominium apartments have been or are being built with 2,900 more proposed, according to the Center City District, a private downtown planning and advocacy group.
 Among recent buyers in Society Hill are Raymond Sterling and Beth Markward, both in their 50's, who are getting a two-bedroom duplex condominium. She is selling her house in Yardley, Pa., and they are keeping his home in Margate, N.J. They will use it as a pied-a-terre because it is close to his work as a dentist and hers as a designer. 
 Mr. Sterling said he liked the central location of Society Hill, and the nearby restaurants and theaters. The couple is paying in the $1 million range for the apartment and expects to close on it in September. Mr. Sterling said he was happy to get the tax abatement that the city has offered developers to encourage new construction, but that wasn't the central reason for his choice -- it is just ''icing on the cake.''
 Tania Rorke, who moved to Society Hill with her husband, Tom, in 1997, and who is president of the Society Hill Civic Association, said she paid in the $400,000 range for her home in 1998 and today it could fetch $800,000 to $900,000. She added that all the new housing developments, assuming they sell, will make the city ''a more vibrant place to live.'' 
 In Society Hill, for instance, she said, Mr. Fefferman's town house project -- which will feature the old-style Franklin street lamps that are a neighborhood fixture -- will be ''a significant improvement'' and help keep alive the charm of the area's past. 
 Although Mrs. Rorke moved to Philadelphia from Hilton Head, S.C., and at first didn't like the city, she has come to love its distinct rhythms. 
 ''Our little enclave has all the conveniences of the city and all the benefits of the suburbs, but it is more close knit,'' she said. ''I come out my front door and see my neighbors and many nights we sit on our stoops and talk.''

HEADLINE: And Now, for the Next Act

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
IN the early 90's, morning commuters used to pour out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue like a swollen river, coursing across 41st and 43rd Streets on their way east. They skirted 42nd Street as if it were blocked by a huge boulder, and the reason was obvious: the prostitutes, pimps, drug dealers, chicken hawks and other hustlers who presided on the parched sidewalks of the Deuce.
 Who among those workers could have imagined that, by the end of the decade, 42nd Street and Times Square as a whole would be safe, even desirable, territory for big media companies, white-shoe law firms and investment bankers? Who could have imagined that the Crossroads of the World would be reborn as a dizzying kaleidoscope of full-color electronic signs and billboards, that the shuttered storefronts along 42nd Street would give way to soaring towers, the B.B. King nightclub, an Internet cafe and a carpeted multiplex. And who could have imagined that, after several decades of slow decay, the transformation would be as fast as a game of three-card monte. 
 Just like those early 90's commuters, we can't conceive of the shape of tomorrow's Times Square. It may remain a vibrant mecca for tourism, entertainment and commerce, or it may assume a totally different shape, like some kind of urban chameleon. 
 Historians, urban planners and Times Square promoters offer an array of predictions, many contradictory. 
 Thomas Bender, author of ''The Unfinished City: New York and the Metropolitan Idea'' and chairman of the history department at New York University, sees the fate of Times Square hinging on the fate of the surrounding area. ''It all depends on whether Midtown Manhattan continues to have the same function 100 years from now as it does today,'' he said, alluding to the area's role now as a place where people live, work and play 24-7. If, like other city centers, Midtown evolves into an office area, then Times Square may be largely vacant after quitting time or serve as an entertainment center mostly for tourists. 
 If any force can turn Times Square into just another bland intersection, it may be the march of real estate activity to the west. Developers today are doing what was unthinkable 20 years ago: building residential towers along a once-industrial stretch of 42nd Street from Eighth Avenue to the Hudson River. There are plans to enlarge the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, and the Jets want to build a new stadium on the West Side. Also, the city is pushing its Hudson Yards project, a plan to transform the tenements and factories of the far West Side into a high-rise residential and office district over the next 30 years. 
 ''To some extent, the future of Times Square is tied up with the far West Side,'' said Mike Wallace, co-author of ''Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898.'' ''What's to prevent these footloose operations from moving west if the Hudson Yards becomes the new hot spot? They hopped from Lower Manhattan to Midtown with alacrity.'' 
 The theater district, a Times Square mainstay, is also under pressure. The district almost died in the 1970's when Times Square became a danger zone for tourists and New Yorkers alike. Today, the theater buildings themselves are old, small and ill-suited for modern musicals. Landmark laws prohibit demolition, but even if they didn't, the theater owners need larger parcels to build up-to-date playhouses. 
 The theaters survived the movie palaces' onslaught, but Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, which operates 17 of Broadway's 35 theaters, said one-third of Broadway houses have been unprofitable for more than a decade.
 Could the district move? ''The environment in Times Square is safe, clean and attractive,'' Mr. Schoenfeld said. ''So I don't see theaters being threatened by anything other than economic strictures created by constantly rising costs and an unsympathetic government. If they wanted to create a cultural center at Battery Park City, the theaters could go there.''
 Moreover, even in the new Times Square, change has already crept in. The golden age of theme restaurants in the late 90's came and went in a blink. Gone are the All Star Cafe, David Copperfield's Magic Underground, Bar Code and World Wrestling Entertainment's restaurant and nightclub. And while developers were encouraged to echo the square's heritage by bringing entertainment ventures to storefronts, the pool of such tenants was shallow and some spaces have been filled with the cellphone stores, drug stores and bank branches common to the street corners of every city. 
 The rejuvenation of Times Square and the arrival of 20,000 new office workers have also driven up rents. A glamorous bar scene flourishes at the Blue Fin in the W Hotel, but with Fleet Bank willing to pay an unheard-of $515 a square foot to rent 5,000 square feet at Broadway and 44th Street, replacing some fast-food restaurants, the square may be in danger of getting bland. 
 Despite all these pressures, some people see a future for Times Square much like its present. Rebecca Robertson, the former president of the state's Times Square redevelopment project, who oversaw the square's transformation in the late 80's and early 90's, doubts that office workers in Times Square will ever go home at 5 p.m. Times Square will always be about entertainment and leisure, she said, even as the specifics change from year to year.
 For example, the giant McDonald's on 42nd Street is only the current incarnation of the popular restaurants and cafeterias of yesterday, Toffenetti's, White's and Bickford's. Similarly, the electronic billboards for men's underwear, musicals and Nasdaq in the 90's mirror the billboards and the neon spectaculars for musicals, toothpaste, pickles and chewing gum in the 30's.
 ''It's a place where its mythology is so embedded,'' Ms. Robertson said. ''Times Square was live theater and movies. One hundred years later, guess what? It's movies and live theater.'' 
 Policymakers are relying on more than the square's heritage. Tim Tompkins, president of the Times Square Alliance, the business improvement district, said his group was addressing the needs of the new office workers by enticing clothing chains to the area, and of tourists, by creating an amphitheater at Duffy Square. 
 The geometry of Times Square, with the broad lanes of Broadway and Seventh Avenue crisscrossing in the ''bow tie,'' also ensures that the intersection will always be special, he said, not to mention the fact that underground, a dozen subway lines converge, bringing more than 250,000 people on the average weekday. Moreover, the square is the only spot in the city where the large illuminated signs that give the area its razzmatazz are not only permitted but required.
 ''Physically, Times Square will always be one of the largest public spaces in New York City,'' Mr. Tompkins said. ''We have a lot of raw ingredients.''

HEADLINE: Pitching Coach Blends Science and Art

BYLINE: By LEE JENKINS

 BODY:
The remaining pieces from Rick Peterson's collection of seascape paintings still hang in his home, subtle reminders of a time and place when they were just about all he had.
 Through his years as a self-described starving artist, Peterson would paint and read and sometimes fast in an attempt to clear his body and mind in a struggle to find the right line on his life.
 Baseball coaches can seem born out of the diamond, carved from fungo bats, polished over the years like glove leather. Ask them when they decided to become coaches and they shrug, as if there was never really a choice.
 Peterson remembers the day, the place and the moment. It was the starting point for a career that has taken him from minor league towns to major league cities, enabling him to advance the science of baseball and open the mind of an industry resistant to change. 
 Peterson, 49, is best known for developing a nucleus of young pitchers in Oakland who led the American League in earned run average the past two seasons. But perhaps more stunning is what the pitching coach has accomplished this season with an aging staff in New York, taking the Mets to the top of the major leagues in E.R.A. and helping them remain competitive despite an inconsistent defense and a relatively unproductive lineup.
 This has all been in the works for more than the past 25 years, since the day Peterson woke up with an empty stomach and decided to take a walk on the beach.
 At the time, he was living in an apartment in San Diego about the size of a freight elevator, just steps from the bustling boardwalk and raucous roller coaster on Mission Beach. He was collecting unemployment, gathering food stamps and working part time as a physical education instructor at a local elementary school for $60 a week.
 On the other side of the country, his father, Harding Peterson, was assembling a team that would win the 1979 World Series and make ''We Are Family'' a civic theme song. Harding Peterson was the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager, but his son was just another kid on the beach, promising his parents he could make it on his own.
 Back then, Rick Peterson was a pitcher still laboring through the minor leagues every summer, but his arm was injured and his spirit was restless. He headed to San Diego in the winter of 1978, not for any reason other than that he was from New Jersey, and San Diego sounded like a place you could warm up and start over, even if you only had $1,000 in your savings account.
 Outside of his dingy apartment, Peterson noticed a flier one day promoting a free seminar with a holistic chiropractor. He wondered if the chiropractor could somehow heal his ailing arm. After Peterson served as a volunteer at the seminar, he asked for a regular appointment. He paid with the only assets he had -- his Impressionist oil paintings of the ocean.
 The chiropractor treated several professional athletes in San Diego and had many prescriptions, including a weeklong fast. Peterson would be allowed to eat raw fruits and vegetables at the start of the week, then only liquids. For a 23-year-old who was looking for something, and did not know exactly what, it was a suggestion worth trying.
 As it turned out, that fast sped up the course of his career. Near the end of the week, he strolled out of his apartment and onto the sand. He has always been tightly built, a fitness fiend, but he was about 25 pounds lighter than normal because he had eaten so little solid food during the winter.
 ''I was walking on the beach and it was like an epiphany,'' Peterson said. ''I wasn't thinking about anything, but all the answers just came to me. You're a teacher. Go teach. Put on your uniform and go teach.''
 For a while, he had wanted nothing to do with that uniform ever again. He had worn it since he was a child, when his father was playing for the Pirates and when he would go into the clubhouse thinking of Roberto Clemente and Willie Stargell as uncles.
 He was still wearing a uniform on what might have been the worst weekend of his career, nearly two decades later, when he threw 200 pitches in a game for Gulf Coast Community College in Florida, and was called to pitch in relief the next day. From then on, Peterson played with a tendon in his throwing arm that was detached from the bone.
 He transferred to Jacksonville University the next year to study psychology and art, but he could still paint the corners of the plate and eventually graduated to the minor leagues with the Pirates, where he spent more time as a player-coach than as a player.
 After one of his final pitching appearances as a regular player, he sat on the floor of a janitor's closet in Alexandria, Va., his arm resting in a dirty sink. The Pirates executive Murray Cook walked into the room, took one look at Peterson and said, ''I think that's it.''
 Peterson spent a large portion of that night staring into a mirror in his hotel room, tears rolling down his cheeks, asking himself, ''So now what?''
 ''I didn't know what I was going to do?'' Peterson said. ''I was going through some serious soul-searching. I wanted to find my life's work and I didn't know what it was going to be.''
 No matter how far he strayed from baseball -- into art and psychology and Eastern philosophy -- he could not leave it altogether.
 When Cook offered him his first job with the Pirates as a minor league coach in 1979, not long after that winter in San Diego, Peterson made it his mission to use baseball as his platform, merging East with West, modern science with old-school hardball. 
 The game was not altogether ready for him. Even his father pushed him to be a doctor or a lawyer, fields better suited to a stable future. After spending over a decade with the Pirates and the Cleveland Indians, and bouncing from the minors to the majors, the Chicago White Sox and the Toronto Blue Jays hired Peterson in the mid-1990's, then fired him in the span of two years. Executives in Toronto said he was too advanced. People in Chicago wondered why he had pitchers throw with their eyes closed, even though the organization's most prominent minor leaguer, Michael Jordan, practiced free-throw shooting with his eyes closed.
 ''There were times then that I thought I'd be out of baseball,'' Peterson said. ''I was frustrated to the point where I didn't know anymore if anyone would let me do what I do.''
 Peterson seemed to fit in better on the team at the American Sports Medicine Institute in Birmingham, Ala., a biomechanics lab where he first joined Dr. James Andrews and Dr. Glenn Flesig 15 years ago to analyze pitching motions, to identify trouble spots on the elbow and the shoulder and to evaluate methods to prevent pitching injuries, particularly in young people. Even now, Peterson has not allowed any of his three sons to pitch until they turn 15.
 ''I saw a real drive back then to use his brain as well as his experience,'' said Flesig, who still works regularly with Peterson. ''He wasn't another piece fitting into the system. Other pitching coaches were doing it their team's way, or the way it had been done for years. Rich was questioning that, not just accepting it. Talking to him is different than talking to other pitching coaches. I find it's more introspective and analytical.''
 Peterson remained in baseball partly because he still hungered to improve it. The A's Billy Beane, already forging a reputation as a rebel general manager, fired the team's pitching coach, Bob Cluck, late in spring training of 1998, even though Cluck was best friends with Manager Art Howe. Beane then promoted Peterson, whom he had hired to be a roving instructor, and watched him cultivate the best young rotation in baseball, helping them avoid the sort of arm trouble that cut short his own career.
 ''It was a tough spot for Rick, but we hit it off right away,'' said Howe, who was also reared in Pittsburgh and has been reunited with Peterson in New York. ''I think he has always appreciated that I gave him the reins and let him do his job.''
 Howe and Peterson can come across as complete opposites, one a mild-mannered traditionalist, the other a high-energy revolutionary. Peterson cannot be confined to the stadium, using his spare time to develop a baseball-specific laptop computer and a software program that computes data on every hitter. Peterson tells his pitchers what a given hitter is batting against 1-2 changeups on the inside corner of the plate, and what they should throw as a result.
 ''There's a reason why we have the best pitching staff in baseball,'' said Tom Glavine, who is making a bid for comeback player of the year. ''When you have a lot of veteran guys, people think they won't listen and buy in. That's not necessarily true. We're smart enough to realize that there are things we can do better, and Rick can teach us those things.''
 Glavine remembers how Peterson gathered the Mets pitchers after a rare rough spot in Arizona this season and presented them with a bag of fortune cookies. Each pitcher took out a cookie and read his fortune. Instead of rolling their eyes, they started joking that their fortunes would change, and, sure enough, Glavine went out and beat Randy Johnson in a 1-0 masterpiece.
 With his mound mantras, his running catch phrases and the motivational sayings that he keeps pasted in his celebrated black book, Peterson has been easy to parody over the years. But Mets pitchers, the only critics who really matter, have become almost protective of their new coach. Not only do they defend his practices, they resent any implication that he is some sort of baseball radical.
 ''What we've done in his first year is not a coincidence,'' Al Leiter said. ''His passion for what he does burns so hot, it's like a white flame. Sometimes I think it's frustrating for him because he wants everyone to have the same passion he does.''
 Leiter is 38, pitching with a frayed labrum in his left shoulder and at that stage of his career when he is starting to wonder what he will do when it is over. He will undoubtedly have opportunities in television, business and politics, but someday soon, he too could be standing in front of a mirror, asking himself, ''So now what?''
 Peterson, the coach who reminds Leiter to rotate his hips, keep his hands low and throw only changeups on 1-2 counts, can also help answer that eternal question.

HEADLINE: Owning vs. Renting? You Can Do the Math

BYLINE: By GARDINER HARRIS

 BODY:
THERE'S a belief that spending money on rent is always wasteful, while buying a home is always smart. This is nonsense. 
 My wife and I recently sold our apartment downtown because we needed a larger one and decided that it made more sense to move into a rental than to buy again. 
 Let's assume you're buying an apartment for $750,000, and that you have $500,000 to invest and must borrow the additional $250,000. While tax deductions on interest payments are helpful, the after-tax expense of borrowing that much money is conservatively about $700 a month, based on a 5.5 percent mortgage rate.
 If you can earn a 4 percent after-tax return on your money, the ''opportunity cost'' of investing $500,000 is $1,666 a month. You have to factor that into your decision as well.
 And then there are the monthly fees after you buy. Most New York City apartments have maintenance fees that, for a $750,000 apartment, often equal about $1,150 a month. On an after-tax basis, this ends up being about $1,000. Insurance is about $250 a month.
 Many people also overlook the one-time costs involved with selling when they consider buying. The broker's fee in Manhattan on that $750,000 apartment will be about $45,000. There's a city transfer tax of $7,500 and lawyers' and closing fees that can add up to $5,000. Then there is the flip tax, which is not really a tax but a fee for the sale of a co-op unit; when we sold our apartment, it was $9,000. 
 Altogether, the one-time costs of selling add up to $66,500, and the monthly costs equal $3,616. There are costs of buying like legal fees, too, that vary. 
 My wife and I figured that we would keep our next apartment for about three years. That meant our true monthly costs for the period would have been about $5,463.
 We got a better apartment by spending $3,400 a month in rent than we ever could have gotten by spending $750,000 to buy -- saving more than $72,000 over the three-year period. 
 Of course, if real estate prices continue to soar, my wife and I are out of luck. But with the average price of a two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan already passing the $1 million mark and interest rates rising, that seems unlikely over the next three years. GARDINER HARRIS

HEADLINE: Is the Stock Market Too Focused on Rates?

BYLINE: By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
INVESTMENT advisers have been warning, to little dissent, that with inflation on the rise, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates aggressively, creating a harsh climate for stocks. 
 But some contrarian investors say that inflation fears have been overstated and that while consumer prices and interest rates may rise further, they are unlikely to climb as swiftly as many people think.
 As a result, the contrarians say, there are bargains to be found, particularly among stocks in industries highly affected by interest rates. They cite industries like construction and financial services that are trading substantially lower than they did in the recent past. 
 ''There has been quite a shakeout,'' said Tim Harris, equity strategist at J.P. Morgan Private Bank in London. He said he had been predicting that the economy would hit ''a sweet spot'' with 3 to 4 percent growth and low to moderate inflation.
 ''The market seems to have jumped straight through that,'' he said. ''It's gone from one extreme to the other,'' meaning from fear of deflation to fear of rapid inflation.
 Mr. Harris is sticking with his benign picture. ''I don't think high inflation or stagflation are factors we'll be living with,'' he said. In an economy afflicted with stagflation, inflation is accompanied by slow growth and high unemployment.
 ''There may be some Fed tightening, but the market's overreacting,'' he said. 
 He estimated that the federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend to one another overnight -- will rise gradually over the next 18 months to 4 percent, from its current level of 1 percent, with little negative effect on stocks. ''I don't think the U.S. economy is a runaway horse,'' Mr. Harris said. ''I do see it growing at a nice, gusty pace.''
 Economists at Gartmore Global Investments in Conshohocken, Pa., also expect the Fed to raise the rate to 4 percent by the end of 2005. They predict small, gradual moves, with all but two quarter-point increases coming next year.
 ''We think rates will go up 50 basis points this year, one rise before the election, one after,'' said Simon Melluish, head of the American equities desk at Gartmore. ''The market's pricing in a good deal more than that,'' he added, maybe 100 basis points, or one percentage point. 
 If the market is overestimating the Fed's tightening, or its impact on the economy, home builders should be worthy investments, Mr. Melluish said. They are now trading at six to seven times his estimate of 2005 earnings. That is very inexpensive, he said, and similar to the valuations in 1984 and 1994, he recalled, when rates rose for several months before reversing course.
 Two builders' stocks he owns are Centex and Lennar. Centex recently had a price-to-earnings ratio of 6.8, and Lennart's was 8.2. 
 Mr. Melluish also likes credit card issuers including MBNA and Capital One. Their prices may be due for a bounce, he said, because enough time has passed since the last mortgage refinancing binge.
 ''Normally a year after a refi boom, credit card companies do well because people start running out of cash,'' he said.
 If rates rise only moderately, Mr. Harris expects companies like insurers, drug makers and food producers to do well. Pharmaceutical and food producers tend to beat the market in times of steady economic growth because their products are necessities, and insurers fare better when prices rise on bonds, which form a big portion of their investment portfolios. Bond prices, which have been falling as interest-rate anxiety has increased, may recover somewhat if those fears prove to be exaggerated.
 He likes several European insurers, including Generali of Italy, Royal and Sun Alliance of Britain and AXA of France. Among food producers, his recommendations include Nestle and Kellogg. And he favors Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer in the pharmaceutical sector. 
 Edward Maran, associate portfolio manager at Thornburg Investment Management in Santa Fe, N.M., has no specific interest-rate forecast, but said he expects that rates will stay low enough not to appreciably depress economic growth. He recommended four stocks that he said should flourish amid such a backdrop: Citigroup, Wells Fargo, Southwest Airlines and Lowe's.
 Citigroup is his choice among big banks because it is involved in activities -- like mortgage lending, investment banking and asset management -- that are especially profitable if rates remain low, he said. 
 ''If rates stay low, consumer and mortgage lending would be strong, as well as commercial lending,'' Mr. Maran predicted.
 Such strength is not factored into Wells Fargo's stock, he said. It trades at 12 times his estimate of earnings next year, and he expects long-term earnings growth of 11 to 12 percent annually, making the valuation look low, he said.
 HE also considers Southwest Airlines relatively cheap at 22 times his estimate for 2005 earnings; its typical multiple is 20 to 40. Airlines are highly affected by changes in economic growth and interest rates, Mr. Maran said, but investors in Southwest seem to be focusing on the prospect of higher rates, not on the economic strength that would produce them. 
 If the economy performs well and rates don't soar, Southwest's stock could double, he said.
 Shares in Lowe's, the home-improvement chain, have fallen with construction stocks and now trade at about 15 times his estimate for 2005 earnings, compared with their usual range of 30 to 40.
 ''People are associating Lowe's with home builders, but we think they're less sensitive to interest rates,'' Mr. Maran said. ''But if rates stay moderate, Lowe's could have a big bounce back.''
 Bill Nygren, manager of the Oakmark and Oakmark Select funds, prefers Lowe's rival, Home Depot. ''The fears are that as rates go up, consumers will have less money for refinancing,'' he said. That, in turn, would mean less money for home improvements. But if rates don't rise much, he said, Home Depot's earnings should increase.
 Mr. Nygren suggested two other beneficiaries of continued strength in housing: Washington Mutual, the bank and mortgage lender; and Fannie Mae, the government-sponsored giant in mortgage lending. Both have fallen on ''concerns that increasing rates will bring an end to the building boom,'' he said.
 Mr. Nygren prefers leaving interest-rate forecasts to others. He called the shift in the rate consensus ''one of the most amazing I've ever seen,'' though he noted that the recent change of mind was not the first.
 ''These are the same people who were telling us a year ago not to be in stocks because of the possibility of deflation,'' he recalled.
