HEADLINE: New Tech Surge in Ireland, And It Feels Like '99 Again

BYLINE: By BRIAN LAVERY

DATELINE: DUBLIN, June 16 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, standing alongside the chief executive of Intel, Craig R. Barrett, cut the ribbon on Monday to open the company's newest semiconductor plant, at Leixlip, outside Dublin. A month earlier, Intel said it would spend $2 billion to build another mammoth factory at the sprawling site. 
 A week before that, eBay's chief executive, Margaret C. Whitman, flew to Ireland to officiate at the opening of her company's newest European location, which will eventually employ 800 people. 
 In April, Google took The Irish Times on a tour of its year-old Dublin-based European hub, so the newspaper could run an enthusiastic article about how the office felt like a California college dorm. 
 Rumors are rife that Amazon.com is touring Web site host operations in Ireland. 
 And so on. 
 In short, it feels like 1999 here. Ireland's $121 billion economy, which rode the crest and crash of the dot-com wave, is once again pinning its hopes on technology investments from across the Atlantic, whether by Internet companies or manufacturers like Intel, just as the American economic revival is allowing companies to look abroad again. 
 Among Ireland's lures are the vast arrays of servers, which serve as hosts for international Web sites and process their data traffic, that were left idle when the technology shakeout four years ago wiped out many over-ambitious start-ups. Many of these barely used servers are now spinning up and humming with life. 
 Likewise, the country's vast Internet bandwidth, including a dedicated undersea cable built five years ago partly with government financing, is once again carrying reasonable amounts of traffic after a long drought. 
 Analysts at Goodbody Stockbrokers, a prominent financial firm here, forecast that Intel's latest investment will, by itself, speed up the growth rate of Ireland's gross domestic product by half a percentage point in 2005, to 4.8 percent. 
 ''I think we've come out in an amazingly resilient state, which does bode well,'' said Jim Power, chief economist with Friends First Asset Management. 
 Lessons have been learned, however, and Ireland is now trying to use the same advantages that put its so-called Celtic Tiger economy on the map in the 1990's in a more mature way. The Industrial Development Authority, the government agency responsible for attracting foreign investors, is using an age-old tool kit of tax and other incentives, but with a tighter focus, often aiming at specific companies rather than whole sectors, said Colm Donlon, a spokesman for the authority. 
 For example, it successfully lobbied the Irish Parliament for a change in the tax code to allow companies that put white-collar operations like headquarters offices and research laboratories in Ireland to write off the investment against taxes, the way manufacturers can with new plants. At 10 percent, Ireland's tax rate for multinational corporations is already one of the lowest in Europe. 
 Universities have tailored engineering programs to meet the requirements of Intel and Hewlett-Packard, and Intel opened a nanotechnology research center at Trinity College in Dublin this year. And the development authority helps streamline Ireland's convoluted planning and zoning process for companies wishing to build significant facilities here. 
 Mr. Donlon predicted that 2004 would be the best year for foreign direct investment, mostly from technology investments, since 2000. 
 The character of the investment is different now, creating far less new employment. Projects assisted by the agency yielded only 2,200 new jobs in the first four months of 2004, about a quarter the pace of 2000, when the full-year total was 23,000. 
 ''We're not looking for investment projects with volumes of jobs,'' Mr. Donlon said -- easy to say in a country where the unemployment rate is 4.4 percent and falling. Instead, he said, the emphasis is on ''high-value investment.'' Intel certainly qualifies -- its latest plans would bring the company's total investment in the country to $6 billion, or about $1,500 for each citizen. 
 The ribbon-cutting on Monday featuring Mr. Ahern, the prime minister, was for a plant known as Fab 24, announced five years ago. The next one to be built here will be Fab 24-2, Intel's fourth in Leixlip and its first outside the United States to use 45-nanometer technology, squeezing more processing power onto each chip than earlier designs. 
 But where Fab 24 employs more than 1,000 people, when Fab 24-2 opens in 2006 it is expected to employ only 400. More important to Irish officials is the $2 billion that Intel expects to spend building the highly automated plant, deepening its stake and, they hope, anchoring Intel in the country for the long term. 
 ''It is symbolically, if not in real terms, the most important U.S. multinational in this country,'' said Mr. Power, the economist, calling it ''a force for modernization.'' He said Intel arrived in Ireland in 1989, when the unemployment rate was 15 percent and hardly anyone here had even heard of stock options. 
 Intel chose Ireland again despite offers from some other countries much more generous than the $120 million Ireland is believed to be paying to land Fab 24-2 (the precise figure has not been made public). In doing so, Irish analysts say, Intel may inspire other technology companies to invest here as well. 
 ''You do attract a quorum of U.S. multinationals -- they tend to feed upon themselves,'' said Gerry Hennigan, a technology analyst with Goodbody Stockbrokers. 
 An Intel spokeswoman, Karina Howley, said the company's employees here had the benefit of 15 years of experience at the top levels of the semiconductor industry. Some 500 of Intel's 4,700 Irish employees have spent more than a year at the company's training and development center in Oregon, accompanied by their families, and another 300 are scheduled to go shortly. 
 If Intel and other multinational corporations here have a growing complaint, it is the rapidly rising cost of doing business here, which seems to climb far faster than consumer inflation. But Mr. Donlon said Intel's plans for Fab 24-2 showed that this country is not at risk of losing more jobs to cheaper locations in Eastern Europe or Asia -- places, he said, that now compete for outsourced service jobs, like those in call centers, that have already come and gone from this country. 
 ''It's the end of the first industrial revolution in Ireland,'' he said, ''and the beginning of the second.''

 Intel's new Fab 24 semiconductor plant in Leixlip, Ireland, will employ about 1,000 people. (Photo by Bloomberg News)(pg. W7)

HEADLINE: Delta Pilots to Seek Talks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The pilots' union at Delta Air Lines Inc. decided yesterday to seek a resumption of contract negotiations with the company, using updated objectives.
 The union's top council passed a resolution during a special meeting in Los Angeles after getting a financial update from economic experts and investment bankers. 
 The company made its latest proposal in January and no substantive talks have taken place this year. 
 ''Delta is under considerable pressure due to increasing fuel costs and declining yields,'' the union, a unit of the Air Line Pilots Association, said in a message to pilots. 
 Delta, which has posted $3.6 billion in losses since 2000, is asking pilots for pay cuts and has said a bankruptcy filing is possible unless it can stem losses. Delta is based in Atlanta.

HEADLINE: Food and Energy Push Producer Prices Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Producer Price Index, a measure of prices before goods reach store shelves, posted the largest increase in more than a year in May, reflecting higher prices for energy and food, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
 In a separate report, the Conference Board said its composite index of leading economic indicators increased 0.5 percent to 116.5 in May, after a 0.1 percent rise in April. The closely watched gauge suggests that the American economy will continue to expand into the fall. 
 Also yesterday, the Labor Department reported that new applications filed for unemployment insurance fell a seasonally adjusted 15,000, to 336,000, the lowest since May 8.
 The Producer Price Index rose 0.8 percent in May after a 0.7 percent rise in April. It was the largest increase since a 1.3 percent rise in March 2003. Excluding energy and food prices, ''core'' wholesale prices rose 0.3 percent in May, after a 0.2 percent rise a month earlier.
 Economists had forecast a 0.6 percent increase in the overall index and a 0.2 percent rise in core prices.
 In May, wholesale prices for energy products rose 1.6 percent for the second consecutive month. The price of crude oil, which peaked at around $42 a barrel in late May, is expected to ease later this year, analysts said.
 Food prices, which are increasing because of more expensive transportation costs tied to higher fuel prices, rose 1.5 percent in May, after a 1.4 percent advance in April.
 Mark Vitner, senior economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said that ''it may be the last blast of really large price increases,'' noting that crude oil prices have come down in recent weeks and that other commodity prices, including lumber, have been softening.
 The question is how the Federal Reserve Board will read the data when it meets at the end of the month to review its interest rate policy.
 ''The real debate is whether this is a significant increase we're seeing here that has to be met with a more aggressive posture from the Federal Reserve,'' said Anthony Chan, senior managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. ''I don't see that in these numbers.''
 The 0.5 percent rise in the Conference Board's index of leading indicators, a forecast of economic activity, was larger than the 0.4 percent that analysts had expected.
 Ken Goldstein, economist for the board, noted that the index had risen in 13 of the last 14 months. The latest numbers, he said, ''reflect a robust economic environment this spring and point to more of the same this summer.''
 Eight of the 10 indicators in the index increased in May, according to the board, a New York-based business group. They were average weekly manufacturing hours, the money supply, interest rate spread, vendor performance, building permits, manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials, a drop in initial claims for unemployment and manufacturers' new orders for nonmilitary capital goods.
 Negative components were consumer expectations and stock prices.

HEADLINE: 9/11 Fund Closes Its Doors

 BODY:
Congress had two purposes in mind when it established the Victim Compensation Fund after 9/11. One was economic: to provide the families of the World Trade Center victims with prompt and fair compensation in exchange for their agreement not to sue the airlines and send them into bankruptcy. The other was to provide a compassionate and collective response to an act of shocking barbarity. 
 The fund officially closed up shop on Tuesday. Though it suffered constant criticism and the occasional lawsuit, it was largely a success. Roughly 97 percent of the 2,973 eligible families filed claims; only 70 chose to risk the uncertainties of litigation, while 30 did nothing.
 This success is a tribute to the industry and the adaptability of Kenneth Feinberg, the special master appointed by the administration to handle the exquisitely difficult task of assigning monetary values to human lives. The volunteers who helped families navigate the paperwork, mainly pro bono lawyers, also made a big contribution.
 Though long on generosity -- the overall payout was $6.9 billion, including 2,675 valid injury claims -- Congress was short on guidance, leaving it to Mr. Feinberg to make sure that families at the lower end of the economic scale got something, while those at the top did not walk away with obscenely high awards. The program taught lessons in tolerance as well as fairness. Gay partners were treated fairly even when state laws were stacked against them, and families of illegal immigrants were assured that they would not be prosecuted if they came forward.
 Everyone hopes, of course, that there will never be a need for a program like this again. But even if a disaster like 9/11 does strike, it seems unlikely that Congress will choose to replicate this program. The price was high, and the chances of total equity virtually nil. Even Mr. Feinberg, an experienced and skilled mediator, agrees that the responsibility he undertook was too great for one person.
 Still, the fund did the task it was given. The airlines got the protection they needed. The American people made a national gesture of sympathy to the bereaved families. The families themselves were able to get compensation through a quicker and simpler route than litigation. In a story with no happy endings, it's good to see this satisfactory one.

HEADLINE: Building-Approval Process Speeded Up in New Jersey

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 17 

 BODY:
While environmental advocates lobbied frantically to stop them, New Jersey legislators approved a bill Thursday that would expedite approval of development in more than one-third of the state. The bill moved with startling speed; introduced three days earlier, it sailed through both houses after leaders struck deals to vote without debate.
 The measure speeds the building-permit process in areas already designated by the state as suitable for development, including most of northeastern New Jersey and the New Jersey Turnpike corridor. It also provides for a state ''smart-growth'' ombudsman with effective veto power over proposed environmental regulations, and representatives in key state agencies to address builders' complaints. 
 The bill was the price exacted for the legislation protecting the New Jersey Highlands, which was hailed as a triumph of environmental preservation when the Legislature approved it just last week.
 Gov. James E. McGreevey, who has cast himself as an antisprawl champion, has had notoriously bad relations with builders. But when a handful of fellow Democrats advocating development projects held up his Highlands bill, he agreed to streamline the permit process. On Thursday afternoon, he twisted arms to get the needed votes. 
 Meanwhile, the environmental advocates who were rejoicing a week ago protested that they had been betrayed. 
 ''This bill was worse than we ever imagined,'' said Douglas O'Malley of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, joining colleagues outside the governor's office. ''We would not have supported the Highlands bill if we knew about this bill.''
 Amy Goldsmith, the executive director of the New Jersey Environmental Federation, said, ''No deal was worth the destruction of 30 years of environmental progress in this state.''
 But the bill's proponents said they were just encouraging builders in developed areas. ''The status quo has not given us smart growth,'' said Micah Rasmussen, the governor's press secretary. ''Half of smart growth is telling builders where they can't build, which we have been doing for two and a half years, and the other half is telling them where they should build.'' 
 Jim Sinclair, the first vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said the bill was ''an important economic development tool, particularly in cities and older suburbs.'' Mr. Sinclair added: ''We still have to meet all the state requirements. This just takes us out of the never-never-land of the permitting process.''
 The areas covered by the bill are designated in the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which divides the state into five categories, from urban to environmentally sensitive. The bill applies to those designated urban and suburban, although much of the acreage is still undeveloped. 
 The plan requires a state agency, in most cases the Department of Environmental Protection, to act on permit applications within 90 days; if it does not, a permit is automatically approved. It also allows a builder to hire a consultant, to be registered with the state, to certify that the application meets state law.
 Local zoning and planning ordinances and local decisions on building permits would not be affected.
 Environmental groups strongly opposed the permit measures. Most said they were disturbed by the appointment of an ombudsman with wide-reaching authority. The ombudsman may not only expedite permit approvals, but may also veto proposed environmental regulations he deems inconsistent with the state plan. 
 Jeff Tittel, the executive director of the New Jersey Sierra Club, said the organization's board had authorized a court challenge to the legislation,. The federal Environmental Protection Agency also raised concerns. Jane M. Kenny, the agency's regional director, who oversaw the New Jersey state planning office when she was a cabinet member under Gov. Christie Whitman, said in a letter to Mr. McGreevey that some provisions ''could contravene a variety of federal permitting requirements, which the state is required to follow.'' 
 Environmental advocates said they knew the Highlands plan would require trade-offs but were taken by surprise when the new bill materialized within days.
 ''The only place there was going to be any debate was on the floor of the Legislature, and they cut that off, '' Ms. Goldsmith said. 
 The Senate vote was 26 to 10, with 4 abstentions. The Assembly vote was 47 to 25, with 2 abstentions. The votes did not follow party lines.

HEADLINE: On Two Continents, Companies Ask Politicians for Accounting Favors

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
JUST when the prospects for accounting reform were at their peak, the bull market came back. And with it came the power of those people who warn that bad things will happen if accountants report unpleasant truths.
 On both sides of the Atlantic, companies that do not want change in an area they deem of vital importance have been pleading with politicians to do something. In the United States, high-technology companies are campaigning against being forced to report the value of stock options as an expense. This week, the House Financial Services Committee voted, 45 to 13, to gut the proposed accounting rule. 
 Powerful senators are opposed to that, so the bill may die. But the committee vote reflects the strength of the technology lobby. Its warnings that America's growth industry could be damaged carry weight.
 In Europe, a similar options rule is sailing to approval. But European banks, primarily though not exclusively French ones, are up in arms over an international accounting rule that would force them to report just how much their investments in derivatives have gained or lost in value -- something American banks have had to do for years. Europeans often ignore such movements, although they can always sell a security to take a profit or loss and smooth the earnings flow.
 In some cases, banks even have two parts of the same institution trade with each other. One part reports a profit from the trade, while the other does not report the offsetting loss.
 The banks say they fear that their reported profits will be too volatile unless the European Commission blocks the rule. They warn that they might be forced to reduce lending just when it is most needed. 
 It had appeared that an intricate dance was going on. Frits Bolkestein, the European Union commissioner for internal markets, demanded changes to reduce the volatility stemming from the rule and to help banks explain away some of the remaining volatility. The International Accounting Standards Board complied, and endorsement was expected.
 But this week, France was joined by Italy, Spain and Belgium in opposing the rule, and Germany did not vote. That is just short of a blocking minority under E.U. rules, and passage is suddenly in doubt. If the rule is blocked, it is not clear what derivative rules, if any, will apply when Europe adopts international accounting standards next year.
 The success of the bank lobbying reflects the dominant position of the banks in financing European business. Their dire warnings command respect from politicians.
 It is time for the people who use financial statements -- the investors -- to speak up. That has happened to some extent in America, where shareholders at several technology companies have defied management and voted in favor of reporting the cost of options as an expense. 
 But in Europe, ''we hardly see users,'' said Hans van Damme, chairman of the financial reporting policy group of the European federation of accountants. Few money managers are involved in such issues, he said.
 The European decision may hinge on what Germany does. Klaus Pohle, who leads the German Accounting Standards Committee, said on Thursday that opposition from small banks led to Germany's abstention but that larger banks and industrial companies were trying to persuade them to support the rule. He said the bigger banks feared that German opposition would damage efforts to make Frankfurt a world financial center.
 The important principle is that accounting rules should be set by independent experts, not by politicians facing heavy lobbying. Investors should shudder if either lobbying campaign prevails.

HEADLINE: Pension Gap At Companies Eases Slightly

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17 

 BODY:
The underfunding of pensions at companies with severe shortfalls eased by 9 percent last year, but the gap remained much worse than five years ago, the nation's pension insurance agency said Thursday. 
 The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which insures the private pensions of about 44 million Americans, said total underfunding at companies with pension shortfalls of more than $50 million dipped to $278.6 billion in 2003, from $305.9 billion a year earlier.
 But the number was up sharply from $18.4 billion reported in 1999, before a recession and stock market declines hit many companies. 
 Big shortfalls persisted in two of the hardest-hit areas, airlines and steel, the agency said. Companies in those industries have made more than 70 percent of the claims against the agency's insurance program since it was created in 1974.
 Companies with pension underfunding of more than $50 million at the end of 2003 were required to file special reports to the agency by April 15, giving details of the shortfalls. While the reports are confidential, the agency is allowed to release the cumulative data to the public.
 Usually the agency waits months to release the data, but its new director, Brad Belt, decided to do it now, while Congress and the Bush administration are discussing possible changes in the pension system. 
 ''Workers and investors have a right to know the financial status of pension plans,'' Mr. Belt said. 
 A pension agency spokesman said it was too soon to tell whether the drop in underfunding was the start of a trend toward improvement.
 The number released on Thursday does not include all underfunding at companies with traditional pensions, because some pension plans are underfunded by less than $50 million.
 If underfunding in all companies with traditional defined-benefit pension plans were included, the total shortfall would be ''significantly higher,'' the agency said. That total was estimated at about $400 billion at the end of last year.
 Defined-benefit pension plans pay a fixed amount at retirement. Apart from the airline and steel sectors, underfunding in these plans was fairly rare in the 1990's bull market, when companies received good returns on their investments.
 But more recently low interest rates and lower returns on stocks have made underfunding more common.
 The severely underfunded pensions -- about 1,050 plans covering millions of workers and retirees -- had $641.8 billion in assets to cover $920.3 billion in liabilities, and were on average less than 70 percent funded last year, the agency said.
 Companies clamoring for help with struggling pension plans spurred Congress to endorse a temporary fix in April, approving $80 billion in relief for companies over two years by changing the way contributions to plans are calculated. The new law also included extra aid for airlines and steel companies.
 With some experts arguing that structural flaws in the pension system need to be addressed, lawmakers are also examining long-term changes.

HEADLINE: City Rent Board Approves Increases Up to 6.5 Percent

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
In a decision that satisfied neither tenants nor landlords, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted last night to raise rents by up to 6.5 percent on the city's one million rent stabilized apartments.
 It was the second consecutive year that the board approved increases that tenant groups warned would be unduly burdensome, but that landlord advocates called woefully insufficient to defray rising costs.
 By a 6 to 3 vote, the board authorized increases of 3 percent for one-year leases, and 6 percent for two-year leases for tenants who pay for their heat and hot water, and 3.5 percent and 6.5 percent for those who do not. That followed last year's increases of up to 7.5 percent, which were the biggest since 1989. 
 In separate votes, the board froze rents on residential hotels for one-year leases, the only kind offered. For lofts, the board approved increases of 2.5 percent for one-year leases, and 5.5 for two-year leases. For all the categories, the increases apply to leases that are renewed from Oct. 1 of this year through Sept. 30, 2005.
 In most years, there is little drama inherent in the board's final vote, because it rarely deviates from a preliminary vote a month earlier. But this year was different, because the board opted during its preliminary vote on May 10 not to offer specific recommendations, but rather a range of increases -- 3 percent to 5.5 percent for one-year leases on stabilized apartments, and 5.5 percent to 7.5 percent for two-year ones.
 The tactic was the idea of Marvin Markus, the board's chairman, and it upset many tenants as well as some landlords. But at the end of the two-and-a-half-hour session last night at Cooper Union, Mr. Markus defended the approach. 
 ''We ended up in the range and I think the process worked,'' Mr. Markus said.
 The annual vote is watched closely because of the sheer numbers of those affected, and the fact that few places around the country have anything remotely similar to the city's rent-stabilized system.
 Of the city's three million housing units, about two million are rentals. Of those, about one million are stabilized and subject to the rates set by the board. 
 Since it was established in 1968 to review rent rates annually for the city's stabilized units, the board has never authorized a rent decrease or freeze. During the high-inflation era of the late 1970's and early 80's, the board sometimes approved increases of up to 14 percent for two-year leases. But for most of the last decade, rents have gone up a few percentage points, in keeping with low inflation and, to a lesser degree, with annual surveys measuring landlord costs and incomes.
 In 2002, for instance, the board ratified increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases, even though the Price Index of Operating Costs, a summary of landlord expenses like utilities and labor, dropped for the first time. Last year, the board authorized increases that were dwarfed by a 16.9 percent jump in the index, the biggest since 1980. 
 This year, landlord costs grew at a much slower pace -- 6.9 percent. Even so, landlords said they were concerned about the possible impact of the city's new lead paint law. 
 The law, which regulates the removal of lead-paint hazards, including dust, from apartments built before 1960, takes effect in August. City officials and landlord groups contended that the cost could be millions of dollars, but tenant groups said that figure was overblown.
 If nothing else, the board's annual vote can always be counted on to attract a raucous and polarized audience. Even before a proposal was made to increase rent by up to 9 percent, the crowd became so unruly, shouting ''Shame on you,'' and ''We say no,'' that Mr. Markus ordered the board to recess for several minutes.
 The 9 percent proposal failed, as did a proposal by a tenant representative to freeze rents. Then came the proposal suggested by Mr. Markus, which eventually passed. 
 Tenants said they found the increases outrageous. ''I think it's really a reflection of the people that the mayor has appointed,'' said Michael McKee, associate director of Tenants and Neighbors, a statewide advocacy group. ''They just don't get it: what real people go through to make ends meet in this city. They're conducting an auction, that's all this is.''
 Landlords were equally angry. ''It's a disgrace when the process meant to stabilize housing is turned into a political circus,'' said Andrew Hoffman, president of Community Housing Improvement Program, a landlord group. ''This is going to lead to widespread abandonment.''

HEADLINE: Saudis Debate Captive's Fate on Web

BYLINE: By NEIL MACFARQUHAR

DATELINE: CAIRO, June 17 

 BODY:
As the deadline loomed for the threatened execution of an American engineer held hostage in Saudi Arabia, with no apparent progress in freeing him, a debate swirled Thursday on Islamist Web sites about whether the killing of foreigners in the kingdom was religiously approved.
 Several efforts were made to persuade the militants to spare the life of Paul M. Johnson Jr., 49, by suggesting that Western expatriates working in Saudi Arabia had been invited and were, therefore, protected.
 But little optimism was apparent that any such proposal would work. In a videotaped threat issued Tuesday over the Internet, Mr. Johnson's kidnappers said the government had until Friday to release all imprisoned militants or they would kill him. 
 Saudi security officials announced no results from many searches around the capital, Riyadh, where Mr. Johnson, a specialist in Apache helicopters who worked for Lockheed Martin, was kidnapped Saturday. The searches seemed to be concentrated in Suweidi, a sprawling, impoverished neighborhood.
 The area is considered a militant hotbed, hometown to about 15 of the kingdom's 26 most-wanted terrorists, including Abdulaziz al-Muqrin, the self-proclaimed leader of a group called Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, which claimed responsibility for the kidnapping and a string of recent violent acts. A cameraman for British Broadcasting Corporation television was shot dead and a correspondent critically wounded early this month while filming in Suweidi.
 In one unusual Web site posting, a Saudi man who wrote that he worked with the kidnap victim and had even discussed Islam with him, tried to extend a religiously inspired, traditional tribal form of protection known in Arabic as ''ijara'' that would forbid killing Mr. Johnson.
 ''I hereby declare my protection and rescue for this man along with all his colleagues who work with us in the company, who ate with us and accepted our gifts of Islamic books which they promised to read,'' wrote the man, identified as Saad al-Moemen. He also described visits by Mr. Johnson to his home and said Mr. Johnson had expressed distaste for American foreign policy.
 Saudi analysts said such protection was usually issued by respected tribal leaders or religious sheiks and there appear to be few such men whom the militants revere. A few clerics still tried, using open forums on the Internet, the medium of choice for the radicals.
 One cleric, identified as Sheik Abu Bassir, reissued a ruling saying that anyone who came to Saudi Arabia with a valid visa should be protected. He wrote that whether foreigners come ''to visit, or for tourism, or for trade, or to study, or to tutor, or for therapy, or to get married, or to hear the word of God, they should be safe and should not be terrorized, should not be assaulted.'' The exceptions, he wrote, are those who come as warriors or spies or to spread corruption, vice and drugs.
 The fatwa, or religious edict, was immediately attacked by a number of readers who said all foreigners, by definition, come to the kingdom with such bad intentions, acting as the vanguard for the American military. ''Whoever gives them security is an apostate,'' read one posting.
 Others scoffed at the idea that an official visa bestowed legitimacy on visitors. ''Who gave them the visa? It is the infidel agent regime,'' read one posting in part. ''So I tell the mujahedeen to keep killing them until the Arabian peninsula is cleared of the filth of the crusaders.''
 Still others were not quite so severe, suggesting to the militants that they try to convert Westerners to Islam rather than killing them, because that way they would be spared from going to hell, and the image of the faith around the world would not be so tainted with blood.
 Reflecting the differences that are rife in the interpretation of Islam, one religious sheik, identified as Abdel Rahman bin Saleh al-Mahmoud, said that Muhammad's followers had commanded that all nonbelievers be expelled from the Arabian peninsula. But it has never been clear, he wrote, whether that includes just the holy city of Mecca or some larger area. Foreigners visited at the time of the prophet, he noted; it was just the idea of permanent communities that was abhorrent.
 One Saudi lawyer prominent in religious affairs said that the religious establishment was preparing to launch a campaign to explain that non-Muslim visitors are permitted. The stated aim of the militants is to undermine the ruling House of Saud by driving from the kingdom millions of expatriates who help keep the economy afloat, especially tens of thousands of Western technicians.
 ''We want to make clear that anyone who comes to the country to live is different from someone coming to invade,'' said Muhsin Awaji, the Saudi lawyer. He said he doubted that any such campaign would change the minds of the militants, and would certainly be too late for Mr. Johnson.
 ''Those very dangerous leaders may not be influenced by anyone from outside,'' Mr. Awaji said. ''But the others, those sympathetic to them, could be prevented from being recruited for their side.''

HEADLINE: A Pool and a Lighthouse? No, a Toll Plaza

BYLINE: By PHIL PATTON

 BODY:
AT the beginning of each episode of HBO's hit television series ''The Sopranos,'' Tony Soprano drives to his home in New Jersey through tollbooths onto the New Jersey Turnpike, passing the rusty viaducts and grim industrial areas that have long made the name Garden State seem ironic. They have also firmly fixed the state's place in the landscape of the national imagination.
 But starting this summer, if the authorities who run the turnpike have their way, that image will change. At the end of this month, traffic will start flowing through a gleaming new $45 million glass and steel toll plaza at Exit 1, the southern end of the turnpike, near Carneys Point, N.J. The building, which spans two dozen lanes of traffic on the main highway route connecting Maine and Florida, is made up of steel trusses and greenish blue glass punctuated by a dramatic curving building. At its center is an 81-foot tower reminiscent of a lighthouse and meant to evoke the Jersey Shore and tourist destinations. 
 And while many of the 50,000 people who drive through the new toll plaza each day might be forgiven for thinking of it more as a source of traffic backups or an irritating delay on the way to a vacation, its chief designer, Zorab Vosganian, has a loftier view. ''It's the new gateway to New Jersey,'' said Mr. Vosganian, an engineer and architect. ''It will change people's impression of New Jersey.''
 Opened in 1951, the New Jersey Turnpike now takes in $440 million a year. There was a time not so long ago when it seemed like the road's tollbooths might be removed. In the 1980's, both Connecticut and New York eliminated at least some toll plazas, and in New Jersey's 2001 gubernatorial campaign, Bret D. Schundler, the Republican nominee, proposed removing tolls immediately. The Democratic nominee, James E. McGreevy, who is now governor, argued for gradual removal. But the tide has turned, both in New Jersey and across the country. More drivers heading to the roads this summer will be taking toll roads, including one in Texas named after George H. W. Bush.
 The growth in tolls is due, in part, to public resistance to increases in gasoline taxes, which have traditionally paid for highway construction and repairs. Automated toll collection systems like E-ZPass, used in seven Eastern states, have also made it faster and cheaper to collect tolls.
 Electronic toll taking makes it relatively easy to change toll pricing -- perhaps raising fees at peak-traffic times and locations or having drivers pay more for low-congestion ''fee ways.'' In traffic-bound areas like Orange County, Calif., HOT (high occupancy toll) lanes are replacing H.O.V. (high occupancy vehicle) lanes. Drivers who choose the HOT lane pay for the privilege at a toll plaza, while those in the more congested lanes drive free.
 When design work started on Carneys Point in 1992, ''the original plan called for enough capacity to handle the busiest time of the year -- Thanksgiving,'' said Dennis Conklin, an engineer at Louis Berger Associates, the project's prime contractor. Among the firm's other projects are the Trans-Amazon highway and the recently built road from Kabul to Kandahar across Afghanistan. Partly because of changing technology, from human toll takers to E-ZPass to high-speed E-ZPass, the project's design changed repeatedly over a decade. There will be two express E-ZPass lanes in each direction, five northbound ticket lanes and 14 southbound toll lanes.
 Mr. Vosganian worked with Ecoplan, an Englewood Cliffs, N.J., architectural firm, in designing the Carneys Point building. Mr. Vosganian and Martin Santini, Ecoplan's chief executive, worked out the lighthouse idea. With the gleaming glass and steel high-tech look of the toll facility, Mr. Santini said, ''we wanted to emphasize the change in New Jersey from the old manufacturing economy to the high-technology one.''
 T HE plaza is also something of a Toll Mahal for toll takers, who will walk across glass bridges to their stations and descend individual elevators to their booths. (At most other toll plazas, toll takers walk underground. ''It's often dark and damp,'' Mr. Santini said. ) The supervisor's curving office, Mr. Vosganian added, is shaped to provide views both north and south; it will function much as an airport control tower or a stationmaster's tower in a railroad yard. 
 But the signature feature of the building is the tower at its center. Although landlocked, the light house is surrounded now by the flow of traffic and soon also by water in a pool at its base. At night, lights sweep across the tower and plaza, suggesting to some the searchlights of a prison escape movie.
 Not so, says Mr. Vosganian, who likes the play of light on the tower. ''It's gorgeous at night. There are indentations in it so the light ripples and shifts.''
 The Vosganian firm also designed the new booths at exit 18W near the Meadowlands. ''They are the northern gateway,'' he said. ''There's a skylight with a computerized system of light in 156 possible colors.'' The lights can be customized like those at the top of the Empire State Building. 
 To reach the new toll plaza, northbound drivers still have to pass over the soaring Delaware Memorial Bridge, from which they get a glimpse of an incinerator-like facility to the right and a DuPont processing plant to the left -- cliched images of industrial New Jersey. The new plaza ''will definitely change people's impression of New Jersey,'' Mr. Conklin said. But, ''they will have a better impression if they don't have to wait a long time at the toll.''

HEADLINE: UNION PACIFIC IS PLANNING TO HIRE 5,000 WORKERS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation, the railroad operator, intends to hire 5,000 train crew workers -- 800 more than its earlier plan -- to help end delays that forced the company to turn away shipments and reduced profit. Richard Davidson, the chief executive, announced the increased hiring at a transportation conference in New York. The crew shortage led to delays after business unexpectedly surged in late 2003 as the economy strengthened. The company, based in Omaha, said last week that second-quarter profit would fall to as little as 60 cents a share from $1.10 a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Archer Daniels Settles Suit Accusing It of Price Fixing

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Closing a final chapter on a nine-year scandal, the Archer Daniels Midland Company said last night that it had agreed to pay $400 million to settle a civil class-action lawsuit accusing the company of fixing prices in the huge market for corn sweeteners.
 The settlement, which was filed in Federal District Court in Illinois late yesterday, is one of the largest ever by a single defendant in an antitrust suit. The money will go to an array of corporate purchasers of the sweetener known as high-fructose corn syrup, including soft drink giants like the Coca-Cola Company and PepsiCo.
 The $400 million will be the largest payment from Archer Daniels in any individual case since the company was first rocked by a price-fixing scandal in 1995, with the disclosure that a senior executive had been recording illegal antitrust conspiracies while working as a cooperating witness for the government. The settlement is subject to court approval, the company said. 
 Archer Daniels, based in Decatur, Ill., has already pleaded guilty in a criminal case to fixing prices with competitors in the markets for lysine, a feed additive, and for citric acid, an additive used in numerous consumer products. But the total settlement in the criminal case reached $100 million, a record at the time for an antitrust case but just a quarter of what the company has now agreed to pay to resolve the lawsuits related to the much larger fructose market.
 A spokesman for Archer Daniels did not return a telephone call seeking comment.
 In recent decades, high-fructose corn syrup has become the sweetener of choice for most consumer packaged goods, supplanting even the use of granulated sugar from cane. The market for the syrup, which is turning up as a prime ingredient in breakfast cereals, soft drinks and snacks, has become huge, totaling hundreds of billions of dollars. 
 The size of the market alone has always made the fructose lawsuit the most potentially damaging of all those faced by Archer Daniels. Economists working for the plaintiffs estimated in court papers that the company's total liability could approach $5 billion. 
 The fructose case has followed a tortuous path over its many years. For some time, it seemed on the verge of collapse, only to be revived by a critical legal ruling issued last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. That ruling, coupled with breakdowns in the relationship between Archer Daniels and Michael D. Andreas, its former vice chairman who served a prison term for price fixing in the lysine market, greatly increased the probability that the company would lose the case in a trial, people involved in the case said. 
 Settlement negotiations were said to have begun in earnest in mid-May, with a direct presentation to the plaintiffs' lawyers by G. Allen Andreas, the chief executive of Archer Daniels, who is a cousin of Michael Andreas. 
 Those meetings, held in Washington, were also attended by two senior members of the Archer Daniels board: Brian Mulroney, the former prime minister of Canada, and O. Glenn Webb, the former president of Growmark, an agricultural cooperative. 
 At first, people involved in the case said, the two sides were far apart, with the plaintiffs seeking a $650 million settlement. Over the course of four weeks, they agreed to the $400 million payment. Under the deal, the money will be delivered to the plaintiffs in one lump sum, three weeks after the deal's effective date.
 The fructose case was an outgrowth of the cooperation provided by Mark E. Whitacre, the former head of the Archer Daniels bioproducts division, which made lysine. In the fall of 1992, Mr. Whitacre informed an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that Archer Daniels was working with competitors to rig the markets for a number of the commodities it sold. He informed the agent, Brian Shepard, that he had personal knowledge of the schemes because he was participating in the price fixing in the lysine market.
 In one of the most involved corporate investigations in history, Mr. Whitacre proceeded to work with the F.B.I. for two years as a cooperating witness, wearing tape recorders on his body and carrying them in his briefcase as he traveled the world, meeting with his competitors in the lysine market. The tape recordings captured both Michael Andreas and Terrance S. Wilson, the head of the corn processing division at the time, actively participating in the price-fixing meetings.
 The investigation came into public view in June 1995, when F.B.I. agents raided the company and descended on the homes of Archer Daniels executives. Rapidly, accusations emerged of the participation by Archer Daniels in antitrust schemes in other markets, including those for citric acid, fructose corn syrup and monosodium glutamate, a food additive. Lawsuits were filed by purchasers of each product line.
 The lysine case became troubled when it emerged that Mr. Whitacre, during the time he had been working with the F.B.I., had simultaneously been embezzling millions of dollars from Archer Daniels and shifting the money into offshore accounts. He was eventually charged with fraud. Because he had violated his cooperation agreement, he was tried for price fixing along with Michael Andreas and Mr. Wilson, who has since left the company. All three men were convicted. 
 Despite the strength of the evidence in the lysine case and the eventual admission by Archer Daniels that it had rigged citric acid prices, the fructose case struggled along. Mr. Whitacre had no role in that marketplace, and his tapes had little in the way of direct evidence that price fixing had taken place with fructose corn syrup.
 In August 2001, Judge Michael M. Mihm of Federal District Court for the Central District of Illinois threw out the lawsuit, ruling that the plaintiffs had no direct evidence of a conspiracy. The appeals court reversed that ruling last year, saying the evidence, while not direct, was ''highly suggestive'' that an illegal conspiracy existed in the market before 1995.
 From there, two critical rulings propelled the case toward settlement. The court held that the tapes of the lysine conspiracy could be admitted as evidence in the fructose case, proving that Archer Daniels executives were willing to engage in the types of wrongdoing described in the class-action suit. 
 The most critical remaining evidence would be the testimony of Michael Andreas, who as vice chairman and onetime heir apparent at the company would most likely have known about or participated in any fructose scheme, particularly given his involvement in the lysine conspiracy. 
 Having finished his prison sentence on the lysine case, Michael Andreas refused to cooperate with the company. Archer Daniels subpoenaed him, demanding that the court compel his testimony. But he successfully argued that he still faced liability from testifying, and the court quashed the subpoena.
 If Michael Andreas were to testify at a trial -- and the plaintiffs were sure to call him -- he would be allowed to invoke his right against self-incrimination. Such a refusal to testify would almost certainly be damaging to the argument of Archer Daniels that nothing improper took place in the fructose market, especially in light of the recorded evidence in the lysine case.
 Archer Daniels then started its effort to settle. 
 Archer Daniels is the fourth company to settle the claims in the fructose case. CPC International agreed to pay $7 million to resolve the lawsuit in 1996. Earlier this year, Cargill Inc. and American Maize Products agreed to pay a combined $24 million.
 With the Archer Daniels settlement, the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company is the sole remaining corporate defendant. A trial is scheduled to begin in September.

HEADLINE: That Invisible Hand Guides the Game Of Ticket Hunting

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
What price Madonna? Well, for me, $139.95. That was for two tickets for Wednesday's show at Madison Square Garden, Section 336, Row H. The tickets, with a face value of $94.50, cost me $59 each. Shipping via FedEx added $9.95. And finally, I paid $11.80, or 10 percent of the price for my two tickets, to an outfit called StubHub.
 To anyone surfing the Web, StubHub.com looks like a ticket brokerage. It's not. The company, founded four years ago by a couple of Stanford Business School students, is a kind of stock market where the only shares traded are tickets to live events: baseball games, Broadway musicals, pop concerts, tapings of television shows, movie premieres, you name it. You can even find lecture tickets. One of the hot tickets on StubHub last month, priced at $350 for two, was to see Oprah Winfrey speak at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. Somebody snapped them up. 
 StubHub, which sells tickets to events all over the United States, does not buy tickets. Instead, it creates a regulated arena in which people who have bought tickets can sell them, and people looking for tickets can buy them, knowing that the tickets are genuine and that StubHub backs them with a guarantee. Some sellers are professional brokers who use StubHub as their place of business. Most are ordinary citizens, usually season ticketholders who want to get cash back for the events they can't attend, or who want to make a nice profit on tickets to high-demand events. Like the auction houses, StubHub makes its money by taking a cut from buyers and sellers, collecting 15 percent of the purchase price of the ticket from the seller and 10 percent from the buyer.
 In principle this business model is as straightforward as Adam Smith. Buyers and sellers mingle in the marketplace and, through free negotiation, arrive at a price that reflects the true value of a commodity. StubHub simply acts as a referee, making sure no one hits below the belt, and collects a commission for its trouble.
 To test the system I started with the New York Yankees. A series with the Seattle Mariners was coming up, just before the Yankees left town for a long road trip. Good tickets would be scarce. Sure enough, when I searched the Yankees' Web site, I found slim pickings for the Saturday afternoon game on May 15. There were a few $18 seats in the last couple of rows, a mile up in the nosebleed sections. No good. This was a half-step removed from watching the game on television in the stadium parking lot.
 I went to StubHub. Lots of tickets there, many priced stratospherically. A seat at field level on the right-field line, just past first base, was $310. Farther out, about halfway to the warning track, a seat just one section back was $185, a tidy profit on a ticket that sells at the box office for $50 in advance or $55 on game day. Those seats, though, had long since been snapped up.
 I settled on two Main Box seats in Section 313, Row G. They were in the right-field corner, just one section above field level. The price was $35 each, or face price for a season ticketholder. This was tremendous value for a sold-out game. I registered with StubHub, creating a user name and password, ordered the tickets, then sealed the deal by providing my credit card number. An e-mail message arrived soon after, confirming the order and informing me that StubHub was contacting the seller to arrange for shipment. My card would not be charged until the seller had confirmed to StubHub the time and method of delivery. A second e-mail message arrived a day later giving the delivery details. The tickets arrived on the Thursday before the game, and the seller was paid by StubHub on confirmation of delivery. On Saturday, under a clear, sunny sky, the Yankees were sending a steady stream of screaming line drives into the right-field corner.
 Eric Baker created the company with Jeff Fluhr as a class project. Both men had worked as investment bankers, and they saw opportunity lurking in the chaotic, highly irrational world of ticket scalping.
 The market, in business-speak, lacked liquidity. It was highly fragmented. Buyers and sellers had a hard time finding each other. Information was scarce, fraud was rampant and pricing was distorted. Two buyers sitting side by side at a basketball playoff might have paid wildly different prices for what was, essentially, the same product.
 StubHub was created, Mr. Baker said, ''to bring together buyers and sellers, and allow people to compare prices and seat locations.'' In other words, to make the market liquid, hence the company's original name, Liquid Seats. Its prime target was the underexploited assets of season ticketholders.
 ''If you have season tickets to the Yankees, that's 81 games,'' Mr. Baker said. ''Unless you're unemployed or especially passionate, there's no way you're going to attend every game.'' StubHub gives ticketholders a way to recoup some of their season's investment. This makes sports franchises happy for several reasons. It encourages season ticketholders to buy season tickets again, and it puts warm bodies in empty seats, where they can buy hot dogs, souvenir caps and programs. The teams also receive a percentage of the resale profits, usually 10 percent. So far, StubHub has signed agreements with nine professional teams in North America, and each team's Web site encourages season ticketholders to sell their extras through StubHub. Ticketmaster, eyeing StubHub's sports profits, recently jumped into the secondary market, signing similar deals with 20 professional teams. 
 StubHub also separated itself from the herd by offering a guarantee. Buyers will receive either the tickets they order or comparable tickets purchased by the company, which insists that it has ways to get its hands on tickets even for sold-out events. In theory, StubHub knows only what its sellers tell it -- that is, that a package has been sent out on this date, with this tracking number. Mr. Baker uses toilet paper to outline the worst-case picture. ''If you open the package and it contains two squares of toilet paper instead of the tickets,'' he said, ''then we debit the seller's credit card for the amount of the purchase.'' By contrast, eBay bows out once buyer and seller have struck a deal. It does not monitor the shipment of purchased items. The eBay system is largely self-policing, with buyers and sellers rating each other's trustworthiness.
 When it comes to antiscalping laws, eBay does more enforcing than StubHub. It automatically refuses a bid that exceeds the legal markup for a resold ticket in the buyer's state, while StubHub relies on the seller to stay within the law.
 From sports, StubHub expanded into other live entertainment events. It also spiced up the formula by approaching individual artists, like Britney Spears, Jewel and Christina Aguilera, and persuading them to put V.I.P. concert tickets on StubHub. Proceeds from the ticket sales go to the artist's favorite charity, and fans with deep pockets buy packages that can include backstage passes, admission to after-concert parties or, in rare cases, a meeting with the artist.
 When I began browsing the StubHub site, I gasped at the V.I.P. prices for the Madonna tour. Who on earth would shell out $1,000 or more for the privilege of seeing Madonna surrounded by a scrum of bodyguards? Well, lots of people. Those tickets quickly disappeared. So did all the $49.50 general-admission tickets being sold through the box office. That left Madonna fans looking for the best tickets at the lowest prices they could find, but now, like airline travelers logging onto Travelocity, Orbitz and Expedia, they could comparison shop. My $59 Madonna tickets, for example, had a face value of $94.50 each. 
 I did a lot of browsing, comparing prices on StubHub with eBay and assorted ticket brokers. For Madonna on Wednesday, StubHub offered tickets in Section 305 for $54. Tickets in the same section, high up and in the middle of right field, so to speak, were being offered on eBay, by a broker, at a starting bid of $150 each. Buyers could skip the bidding process and buy them outright for $399 apiece.
 But eBay also had bargains. A ticket in Section 329, high up and just behind stage left, opened at $20, attracted 17 bids and sold at $45, or just under the general-admission price. Prices on StubHub vary, too. Two tickets in Section 336, Row H, were offered at $59. Two tickets in Row L of the same section were $101. Several online brokers were offering tickets in Section 336 for about $150, a price that had dropped, by press time, to face value. As the concert approached, Ticketmaster also began selling the $49.50 tickets again. Like commodities traders, buyers can bet that an event will sell fewer tickets than predicted, and wait for falling prices to deliver a bargain.
 Once I had the hang of StubHub I succumbed to day-trader syndrome. I began searching the site neurotically, comparison shopping for events that I had no intention of attending. Ms. Winfrey fascinated me; tickets to her speaking engagement, with a face value of $45, sold for about $180 on eBay and $315 on StubHub. A mere trifle. Hot playoff tickets can command prices in the thousands. And when StubHub auctioned tickets to the live finale of the reality show ''Survivor: All-Stars'' on CBS, two tickets sold for $3,300. Like too many other people, I wanted to see Smarty Jones race for the Triple Crown at Belmont Park. A really good ticket, right at the finish line, sold on eBay for $1,025. Anything remotely near the finish line would have set me back at least $500 on StubHub.
 In the New York metropolitan area, the main event categories on StubHub are sports, theater, music and comedy. At the moment, television boils down to one show, ''The Daily Show,'' with ticket proceeds benefiting the Museum of Television and Radio. A category called Family Tickets is also represented by just one event this week, ''Dragon Tales,'' at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y.
 Classical music lovers will look in vain for tickets; StubHub has nothing for them, although that may change in the next year or so. StubHub establishes categories when enough ticketholders express a desire to sell. That has not yet happened for classical music in New York, or anywhere else, as far as I can tell. The Metropolitan Opera alone should be able to support a booming market. Let's get some liquidity going.
 Sometimes, not even StubHub can help. At press time, it had no tickets for Saturday matinee performances of ''Avenue Q'' through Sept. 4. But I found a secret source with a few tickets to spare. Don't tell anyone. It's called the box office.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

United Is Denied Request For Loan Guarantees
A federal loan board rejected United Airlines' application for $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees, saying that it thought the airline could survive on its own without government help.
 United, the nation's second-largest airline, has kept operating normally in bankruptcy, and the decision was not expected to have any immediate effect on travelers or the airline's employees. But its plans for emerging from bankruptcy depended heavily on winning the loan guarantees, and the board's decision was a serious setback. [Page A1.]

Atmos Energy to Buy TXU Unit
Atmos Energy said that it had agreed to acquire the natural gas operations of TXU for $1.93 billion. The deal would create one of the nation's largest distributors of natural gas. The purchase would substantially enlarge Atmos's business in Texas, giving it control of 6,800 miles of transmission pipelines in the state and many new customers in north Texas. Both companies are based in Dallas. [C5.]

Grasso Seeks Change of Court
In a surprise maneuver, Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has asked that the suit over his pay be moved from state to federal court. [C3.]

Europe Said to Support Music Deal
Despite earlier objections, European regulators are now set to approve the merger of the music divisions of Sony and Bertelsmann, people close to the case said. [C4.]

Producer Prices Rose in May
The Producer Price Index for May posted the largest increase in more than a year. [C3.]

Stock Indicators Decline Slightly
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 2.06 points, at 10,377.52. The broader gauges also finished lower. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 14.56 points, to 1,983.67. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 1.51 points, to 1,132.05. [C5.]

Pension Gap Eases Somewhat
Underfunding of pensions at companies with severe shortfalls eased by 9 percent last year, but the gap remained much worse than five years ago, the nation's pension insurance agency said. [C3.]

Rigas Lawyer Cites Flawed Case
John J. Rigas, the founder of Adelphia Communications, fell victim to a ''rush to judgment'' by federal prosecutors who have failed to prove their fraud case against him, his lawyer said in closing arguments. [C5.]

Putin Says Russia Will Aid Yukos
A day before an expected court ruling that could cost the Russian oil giant Yukos billions of dollars in back taxes, President Vladimir V. Putin said his government would do its best to assure that the company would not go bankrupt. ''Russian authorities, the government, and the economic officials of our country are not interested in seeing Yukos go bankrupt,'' Mr. Putin told reporters. ''The government will try to do everything not to topple this company,'' he said. [World Business, Section W.]

Senate Confirms Greenspan
The Senate approved President Bush's nomination of Alan Greenspan to serve a fifth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. [C5.]

Newsday Circulation Was Inflated
Circulation figures at Newsday and the Spanish-language daily Hoy were inflated by as much as 19 percent for the year ended in September, Newsday said. [C4.]

Olympics More Costly Than Planned
With the opening Olympics ceremony just six weeks away and anxiety mounting over whether Athens can deliver a successful Games, Greece's government said that the cost of staging the event was at least 30 percent higher than forecast. [A10.]

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 665 words

HEADLINE: Bush Spends A Long Day (And Night) On the Trail

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: TACOMA, Wash., June 17 

 BODY:
President Bush swooped into Spokane on Thursday night to raise $750,000 for Representative George Nethercutt, the Republican who is challenging Senator Patty Murray for a seat in a politically competitive state important to Mr. Bush's re-election chances in November.
 Mr. Bush's two-hour stop came after he spent a fractious day on the other side of the country in Washington, D.C., focused on the commission investigating the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the intense arguments over ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda. The president's four-and-a-half-hour flight here, for events that did not end until after midnight East Coast time, showed how much effort the White House is devoting to his re-election campaign in the middle of the persistent debate about national security. 
 ''The right person to represent the state of Washington in the United States Senate is George Nethercutt,'' Mr. Bush told more than 600 people at the Spokane Center complex, who had spent $1,000 each to attend, adding that they should work hard to get people to the polls.
 ''While you're getting them to vote for George, why don't you get them to vote for me as well,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Both of us are going to carry this state. And we're going to because we've got optimistic plans to make this country safer, stronger and better.''
 Optimism was Mr. Bush's other message in a speech he delivered to a business group in Washington earlier in the day promoting recent improvements in the economy and castigating, although not by name, Senator John Kerry.
 ''There are modern-day economic pessimists who are quick to offer dire predictions and complaints,'' Mr. Bush told the National Federation of Independent Businesses at the JW Marriott Hotel. ''But you know what? They do not offer pro-growth economic policies.'' 
 Such people, the president added, ''can find the dark cloud, but they can't see the sunshine, and they don't know where to take the country and they don't know where to lead.''
 Mr. Kerry, the all-but-certain Democratic presidential nominee, is in the middle of a two-week campaign attacking Mr. Bush's economic record, which his advisers say should be judged on the president's entire term in office, not the turnaround of recent months. In Ohio and New Jersey on Tuesday, Mr. Kerry told audiences that the Bush White House has been willing to settle for policies that leave the middle class saddled with endless debt and rising health care costs and tuition.
 Phil Singer, a Kerry campaign spokesman, responded to Mr. Bush's speech in Washington by saying, ''It's ironic that a president who has overseen record deficits and the biggest increase in spending since World War II is criticizing a candidate who plans to cut the deficit in half and restore fiscal discipline.''
 In Spokane, Mr. Bush gave his standard endorsement speech for Mr. Nethercutt, and said as he almost always does for every other male candidate that he and the congressman had married above themselves. ''The good news for me is that Laura hasn't run me off yet,'' Mr. Bush said.
 Mr. Bush included in his speech a lengthy quotation from a 1946 New York Times article describing the occupation of postwar Germany, some two years before the Marshall Plan began pouring billions of dollars into what became a successful reconstruction.
 ''In every military headquarters, one meets alarmed officials doing their best to deal with the consequences of an occupation policy that they admit has failed,'' Mr. Bush read aloud from the article.
 The lesson for Iraq, he said, was optimism.
 ''Fortunately, my predecessors were not pessimistic people,'' Mr. Bush said, adding that ''someday an American president will be sitting discussing world peace with a duly elected leader from Iraq.''
 On Friday, Mr. Bush is to appear at stops in Fort Lewis, Wash., and Reno, Nev., Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, who ran a bitter race against Mr. Bush in the 2000 presidential primaries.
